question: open vs closed back headphones . What are the advantages and disadvantages for them and which ones are used for what ? Edit : thanks to everyone who took the time . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: Open ones usually make the sound stage bigger , you will be able to differentiate different instruments in an orchestra . It 's just closer to listening to something in a big room . But it 's horrible for travelling around , you will hear all the noise around you and everyone around you will have to listen to your shitty music . Closed headphones cancel noise a lot better , you 'll be able to listen in noisy / busy environments without problems . For gaming it may be preferable or you might have some feedback to your microphone . That being said it does n't really matter for listening pleasure , everyone has his own preference . I like my open headphones for playing guitar , especially useful when i try to play along to a song but do n't want people to hear me practice , i can just turn up my sound system and use the headphones for guitar and i 'll be able to hear both quiet well . Or sometimes in the evening i use them as speakers , if you turn the volume up it 's usually good enough to listen to some silent music while you fall asleep . On the other hand i hate them for gaming , i sometimes confuse what happens around me for things in game and people on team speak hear my game sound when i turn it up too much . Using the closed phones allows me to leave the world behind and just life in the game for a while . For travelling / noisy environments i never carry around headphones ( i do n't know why anyone does ... i guess mostly for posing reason ) . My rather cheap in ear headphones cancel the noise and have good enough sound for my daily train rides . With all the noise in the background i wo n't enjoy the higher quality from the other headphones anyway . And i would hate to break my better headphones by accident while they are in my bag . Edit : And while i love listening to old guitar songs , concerts and things like that with my good headphones ( they 're like goosebumps guarantee for good songs ) i feel like most party / dance music really does n't do to well with good speakers ... you really start to notice cheap effects and it just makes some songs unenjoyable for me , not sure if anyone else has noticed the same . Usually headphone people tend to only brag about how good the sound becomes with great headphones .

Open : Your ears sit in a cup which is open to the atmosphere . Advantages : Supposedly a more " open and expansive sound " Disadvantages : They leak noise a lot . ( both ways ) thus quiet details in music can get lost Closed : Your ears sit in a sealed cup not open to the atmosphere Advantages : Supposedly better bass and less noise intrusion from outside ( and less noise leakage ) Disadvantages : Supposedly a more " Shut - in " and less dynamic sound Fun fact : Closed earphones are not fun if you have blocked Eustachian tubes

The physical construction of open back headphones means that your ear is still exposed to everything around you . This tends to make the sound more " airy " and " expansive " - some would say improving the " soundstage " . If you are unfamiliar with the concept of " soundstage " , this is a term loosely describing the headphone 's ability to recreate the sound in 3 - dimensional space ( think of it kind of like the difference between having 2.1 speakers and surround sound ) . Since the noise does n't reverberate in the headset on open back models , the bass response tends to be weaker than closed back headphones , but this can also improve the clarity of the sound . Because you are open to the environment , noise leaks to and from the headset as well : if you are not in a quiet environment the background noise will leak a lot into what you are listening to , and people nearby would be able to hear it quite clearly . Closed back headsets are the opposite to the above . Your ears are isolated from the environment . The sound tends to be " fuller " and " more powerful " - the soundstage is typically worse ( sounds more " in your head " compared to open - back headphones ) , though this can vary a lot still depending on a bunch of factors . Noise reverberates in the headset , tending to make the bass frequencies sound more powerful , though this can also obscure some of the finer details ( sometimes described as having a " muddy " bass for instance ) . You are isolated from the environment , and background noise will be greatly muffled and obscured , hearing only the noise the headphones are playing . The usages for each vary , but it 's basically personal preference . Each type just provides a different listening experience and it 's subjective what people will prefer . The main drawback of open - back headphones is the noise leakage , meaning they typically are n't suitable for everyday use ( you would n't be able to use them on a bus or train for instance ) . A niche application for open - back headphones that comes to mind is competitive gaming - competitive gamers value the excellent soundstage which gives great directional cues ( for instance , picking the direction of footsteps in a shooter game ) and the more balanced sound signature can prevent the game 's sound effects from becoming overwhelming ( stop loud , bassy sound effects like explosions from interfering too much with audio cues - conversely some may prefer closed back headphones for the opposite reason in that it makes sound effects like this sound more weighty and immersive )
generated_answer:
Open-back headphones have a design where the ear cups are not sealed and allow sound to pass through them. This can give a more natural and open sound, as if you are listening to speakers in a room rather than headphones on your head. The sound from open-back headphones may also be more spacious and have a wider soundstage, which can be beneficial for certain types of music and audio recording. 
On the other hand, closed-back headphones have a design where the ear cups are sealed and do not allow sound to pass through them. This can provide a more isolated listening experience and can be helpful for blocking out external noise. Closed-back headphones are often preferred for noisy environments or for use in situations where you do not want others to hear what you are listening to. They are also often used for monitoring in recording studios, as they can help to prevent sound leakage into microphones. 
Both open-back and closed-back headphones have their own advantages and disadvantages, and which one is best for you will depend on your specific needs and preferences. Some people prefer open-back headphones for their natural sound, while others prefer closed-back headphones for their isolation and ability to block out external noise. Ultimately, it comes down to personal preference and the specific use case.

question: common core math Could somebody explain common core math . I 'm not strong with math but I 'm good with understanding concepts . But this is just confusing . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: Most of the replies here are conflating Common Core requirements with particular teaching methods or problem solving algorithms . That 's incorrect . The Common Core is merely a list of things that students * should know * and * should be able to do * . A direct copy & paste from the Common Core : > [ Students should ] Use addition and subtraction within 20 to solve word problems involving situations of adding to , taking from , putting together , taking apart , and comparing , with unknowns in all positions , e.g. , by using objects , drawings , and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem . > [ Students should ] Solve word problems that call for addition of three whole numbers whose sum is less than or equal to 20 , e.g. , by using objects , drawings , and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem . URL_0 Further , the Common Core is standardized across states . That means that whichever Common Core state you live in , you should be able to do either of the things I listed . The particular details of how to teach a student to do these things is * entirely the responsibility of their school * . As long as the student can " Solve word problems that call for addition " by the end of Grade 1 , the Common Core does n't care how they do it or how they were taught .

The common core is designed to teach math in a manner consistant with how people think . For instance , 17 from 52 . The way I was taught to so this problem was to write 52 17 And then substract 7 from 2 , which is n't helpful , so you ' borrow ' a 10 from 50 ' and substract 7 from 12 . Cross out the 5 , write a 4 in its place , and write ' 5 ' below the 7 ( 12 - 7 ) . And so on . But that 's not how we subtract naturally . We think " well 52 is close to 50 and 17 is close to 20 . 50 - 20 is easy : 30 . Then add the two you ignored from 52 : 32 , and the 3 you ignored going from 17 to 20 : 35 . " Each of us may choose arbitrary places to put those values ( " 52 is close to 50 ' 17 is close to 15 " ) but the process is the same . We break hard problems down into easy problems and then add back the bits we skipped . That 's part of how the common core teaches math . The old way works , but students came out the other end not knowing why . It produced generations of students who did math purely by cargo cult thinking .

Common core addition is known as the cashier 's method , because cashier 's used to use it to quickly compute correct change in their heads . Essentially , you round numbers to the 10 's & 100 's to add quickly add them . For example , 42 +13 . Change that to 40 +10=50 & 2 + 3=5 then 50 + 5=55 . For a bigger number , 239 + 829 would be 200 + 800=1000 & 40 + 30=70 so you get 1000 + 70= 1070 minus the two you added = 1068 . You 've probably heard a lot of objections to common core , like it 's too complicated or it takes too long or it 's telling teachers how to teach . In reality , these are all false arguments . Parents do n't like it because they do n't intuitively understand it , but that does n't make it wrong or harder . Anything takes a long time when you 're first learning . Lastly , common core is a set of nationwide standards , it is not a curriculum , it 's not a test , it 's not a government mandate . [ Dr. Solomon Friedberg ] ( URL_0 ) , Chair of the math department at Boston College explains in more detail why common core math is really a good thing , and why all the objections to it are based on wrong assumptions .
generated_answer:
Common Core math is a set of math standards that have been adopted by many states in the United States. These standards are designed to help students develop a deeper understanding of math concepts and to be able to apply those concepts to real-world situations. 
One of the main goals of Common Core math is to encourage students to think critically and solve problems in creative ways. This means that instead of simply memorizing formulas or procedures, students are encouraged to understand the underlying concepts and to use those concepts to solve problems. 
For example, instead of just memorizing the steps to multiply two numbers, students are taught to understand what multiplication means and how it can be used to solve real-world problems. This might involve using pictures or diagrams to represent the problem, or using physical objects to model the problem. 
Overall, the goal of Common Core math is to help students develop a strong foundation in math so that they can be successful in higher level math courses and in their future careers. Is there anything specific you'd like to know about Common Core math?

question: Why are hate crimes illegal ? If the crime itself is already illegal , what does the reason have to do with it ? Does the " hate " involve additional repercussions ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: Reason is pretty much always considered in crimes . That is why we have first , second and third degree murder . The reason hate crimes get higher punishments is because it is not just an attack against one individual , you are also , indirectly , attacking a whole group of individuals , causing fear and unrest . If you kill Jack because he slept with your wife , you are only a danger to Jack . Tom does n't have to fear you , because he is n't sleeping with your wife . If you kill Jack because he is gay , you are not only a danger to Jack , you are also a danger to every other gay guy , and you might definitely be causing some very realistic fear in Adam , who is also gay .

Because hate crimes have the added effect of terrorizing the victim 's minority community . For instance : A gang goes around beating up black people . In addition to the damage done to the individual victims , all black people in that area feel like they have to be more careful when they go out , and it reduces their quality of life .

As far as I understand it , it 's to distinguish things like spray painting your name on a wall from spray painting " faggot " on a gay person 's house . They 're both crimes of vandalism but one of them is a more serious version of the other , because now in addition to someone having to clean the paint off , someone is also being harassed and hated and generally made to feel unsafe . And I do n't mean it 's specific to vandalism , I 'm just using that as an example
generated_answer:
Hate crimes are considered more serious than other types of crimes because they are motivated by hatred or bias towards a particular group of people. This can include crimes such as assault, vandalism, or theft that are committed because of the victim's race, religion, ethnicity, sexual orientation, gender, or other characteristics. 
The reason that hate crimes are illegal is because they are harmful not only to the individual victim, but also to the community as a whole. When someone is targeted because of their identity, it can create fear and mistrust within that group and can have a ripple effect on the entire community. 
In addition to the punishment for the crime itself, hate crimes often have additional penalties because they are considered more serious. These additional penalties may include longer prison sentences or fines. 
Overall, hate crimes are illegal because they are harmful to both the individual victim and the community, and they are seen as a more serious offense than other types of crimes.

question: Why do we close our eyes when we sleep ? In debth biology explanation :) Please explain like I'm five.

There are a few reasons why we close our eyes when we sleep. One reason is to protect our eyes from dust and other particles that might irritate them. When we are awake and our eyes are open, we blink to keep our eyes moist and to wash away any dirt or dust that might have gotten into them. However, when we are asleep, we don't blink as much, so closing our eyes helps to keep our eyes moist and protected. 
Another reason we close our eyes when we sleep is to help our brain relax. When we are awake, our eyes are constantly sending signals to our brain about what we are seeing. These signals can be distracting and make it harder for us to relax and fall asleep. By closing our eyes, we block out these signals and give our brain a chance to rest and recharge. 
Finally, closing our eyes can help us to feel more comfortable and cozy when we are sleeping. It can be nice to have a sense of darkness and privacy when we are in bed, and closing our eyes helps to create this feeling. 
So, to summarize, we close our eyes when we sleep to protect our eyes, to help our brain relax, and to feel more comfortable and cozy.

The iPhone uses a proprietary connector called a Lightning connector, rather than the micro-USB connector that is used by many other devices. Apple has used the Lightning connector since 2012, when it replaced the older 30-pin connector that was previously used on the iPhone. 
There are a few reasons why Apple decided to use the Lightning connector instead of micro-USB. One reason is that the Lightning connector is smaller and more compact than micro-USB, which allows it to be used on devices with smaller form factors, such as the iPhone. Additionally, the Lightning connector is reversible, which means it can be plugged in either way, making it easier to use. 
Another reason is that the Lightning connector is able to transmit data as well as power, which means that it can be used to connect devices to a computer for transferring files, or to connect to other devices for things like audio or video output. The micro-USB connector is primarily designed for charging and does not have this capability. 
Overall, the decision to use the Lightning connector was made by Apple in order to give them more control over the design and functionality of their devices, and to offer features that are not possible with micro-USB.

question: What is silica gel ? What does it do and how does it kill you ? I see so many of these in the warehouse inside shipping boxes . I 'm just so curious Please explain like I'm five.

generated_answer:
Silica gel is a small, hard, porous bead made of silicon dioxide. It is often used as a desiccant, which means it absorbs moisture from the air. Desiccants are used to help prevent things from getting damp or moist, which can cause them to spoil, rust, or become moldy. 
Silica gel is often used in shipping boxes to help keep the contents dry during transportation. It can also be found in products like shoe boxes and food packaging to help extend the shelf life of the products. 
Silica gel is not toxic and is not dangerous to humans. However, it is not meant to be eaten, so it is important to keep it away from children and pets. Swallowing large amounts of silica gel can cause digestive problems, so it is best to avoid swallowing it. 
Overall, silica gel is a useful and safe product that helps to keep things dry and prevent damage or spoilage.

When the battery is being charged, the coulometers measure the amount of charge going into the battery and store this information. When the battery is being used to power the device, the coulometers measure the amount of charge being used and update the stored information accordingly. 
The device's battery meter then uses this stored information to display the current charge level on the device's screen. So, the battery doesn't actually "put off" more energy when it is full. Instead, it is the coulometers inside the battery that keep track of the charge level and let the device know how much battery life is left.

The device may also connect to the internet and check with an online server to get the most accurate time possible. question: How is body fat " burned " off during excercise ? I 've heard something about fat is expelled as CO2 when you breath out but I do n't fully understand the whole process . Anyone know how it works ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: Basic overview : Your body demands energy . It breaks down fat molecules into lower energy molecules , and uses the energy . The chemical reaction looks like this : Fat + O2 - > H2O + CO2 So , you 're body takes in oxygen when you breathe . That oxygen reacts with the fat molecule , that has hydrogen , oxygen and carbon to form carbon dioxide and water .

You have a certain number of fat cells . Even when you lose fat , you keep the same number of fat cells . When you gain weight in the form of fat , what 's happening is that your body is storing energy ( in the form of triglyceride or triglycerol , ca n't remember which ) inside your fat cells . When fat is " liberated " from your fat cells , a process called lipolysis will turn that triglyceride into glycerol and three free fat acids ( FFAs ) . The FFAs enter the blood stream and make their way to the muscles . The muscles say , " ermagerd , gimme " and hand the FFAs off to their mitochondria . A chemical process occurs that splits up the FFAs super long chains of carbon atoms , turning it into something called Acetyl - CoA. This molecule can be used to make adenosine triphosphate ( ATP ) , which is what powers a cell . During all of these processes , the fatty acid is oxidized ( I forget how many times ) . Fatty acid is mostly made of carbon . Carbon + oxygen = CO2 . So one of the ways you get rid of the fat you 've used is to breathe out . Please note that I am not a scientist , and am happy to be corrected by someone who is .

The ELI5 answer is , you breathe and sweat it out . Fat is a great source of energy , about 3500 calories per pound . When you use more calories than you intake , your body converts fat ( an organic compound made of carbon , oxygen , and hydrogen ) into CO2 and Water ... Ie , sweat and breath . The energy from this conversion is used by your body to move your muscles , etc .
generated_answer:
When you exercise, your body uses stored energy in the form of fat to fuel your muscles. Your body has a limited amount of energy stored in the form of glycogen (a type of carbohydrate) in your muscles and liver, and when that runs out, it turns to fat as an energy source. 
Here's how it works: 
1. When you start exercising, your body breaks down glycogen stored in your muscles and liver into glucose (a type of sugar) to use for energy. 
2. As you continue to exercise, your body uses up more and more glycogen and starts to use fat as an energy source. 
3. When your body uses fat for energy, it breaks down the fat molecules into smaller parts, including glycerol and fatty acids. 
4. The glycerol and fatty acids are then taken to your cells, where they are used to produce energy through a process called cellular respiration. 
5. During cellular respiration, oxygen is used to convert the glycerol and fatty acids into energy, and carbon dioxide (CO2) and water are produced as byproducts. 
6. The CO2 is expelled from your body when you breathe out, and the water is expelled through urine and sweat. 
So, to answer your question, when you exercise, your body burns fat by using it for energy and releasing the byproducts (CO2 and water) through your breath, urine, and sweat.

question: when you waterdamage your phone ect . what actually happens that stopps it from working ? iPhones , laptops ect Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: Getting electronics wet causes a short circuit . Basically , circuits are set up so that electricity can only flow in certain , predictable paths . Water creates bridges that are n't supposed to be there , letting the electricity flow in ways it 's not supposed to , and that can cause damage .

On the other hand , distilled water wo n't damage your electronics until enough pollutants get into the water to create the electric pathways for it to short circuit . You can dip a unplgged mother board into distilled water and let it dry , it 'll be fine .

Worked in a mobile phone repair centre for a fair while . We repaired / cleaned water damaged phones on a daily basis . There 's basically two causes of damage . 1 ) When the phone first gets wet , the water can short out the circuit . This can cause damage , but ussually phones are low power and so ca n't really damage themselves with a short circuit . It 's possible , but not that common . This sort of damage we did n't really bother to " repair " . We just randomly replaced components until it works again then bill the customer for all the parts . 2 ) After the water dries out ( leave phone in rice overnight trick ) , the phone will most likely work again . However the water drying up leaves behind whatever chemicals were in the water on the metals used in the circuits . Left unchcecked , this will eventually lead to corrosion . Corroded metals do n't conduct electricity properly or can break a connection entirely . This will stop your phone working . This is why a water damaged phone can start working again the next day but then eventually a few weeks / months later stop working properly and eventually degrade to the point it no longer works at all . This is the corrosion slowly breaking your phone . We repair this sort of damage by resoldering the connections that look corroded / broken and hoping for the best . If this does n't work we just tell you your phone is fucked and sell you a new one . To repair water damaged phones that still worked , we would take all the components out , scrub the PCBs and all the connections with a solvent and a tooth brush to effectively wash them out , then dry them and put them back together . Getting this done within a week or two of the water damage generally guarantees no lasting impact on your phone . However since the phone often starts working again after the original water damage , people often figure it 's fine and do n't bother with any repair work while corrosion slowly eats their phone from the inside . Most phones I ever saw that were no longer working , had some level of corrosion on the circuit components . Simply cleaning the corrosion off with solvent and a toothbrush fixed a surprising amount of them .
generated_answer:
Water damage can cause a number of problems with electronic devices such as phones and laptops. When water gets inside the device, it can cause short circuits, which are electrical connections that happen unexpectedly. These short circuits can cause the device to stop working or function improperly. 
Water can also cause corrosion, which is when the metal parts of the device start to break down and deteriorate. This can make the device stop working properly, or even completely stop working. 
Additionally, water can cause the device to rust, which is when the metal parts start to turn red and become covered in a reddish-brown substance. Rust can also cause the device to stop working properly or stop working altogether. 
Finally, water can cause the device to malfunction or stop working if it gets into the device's hardware, such as the motherboard or other important components. These components are responsible for controlling the device's functions, and if they become damaged by water, the device may stop working.

question: Why do people disagree with stem cell research ? am i missing something here ? ? Please explain like I'm five.

question: Why do I have to pay taxes on money I inherited ? I 'm talking about less than $ 50,000 , not millions . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: The tax is for the " privilege of transferring wealth upon death . " However , in the USA you do n't have to pay federal taxes on the first $ 5.4 million or $ 10.8 million for inheritance from married people . There is a generation skipping tax that could be applicable if grandparents leave money to their grandkids .

If that money was in an IRA or another tax deferred account , your parents never paid taxes on it in the first place . They would be required to pay taxes on it as it is withdrawn , and so are you . The deceased 's IRA rolls over into what is called a beneficiary IRA . You have to make required withdrawals from it when the deceased turns 70 , just as they would ... but the withdrawal amount is based on your life expectancy , so if you are young , the amount would be very small , and it would continue to grow tax free , likely in excess of the withdrawal amount . Or you could liquidate it immediately , and pay about half of it to taxes and penalties . Option # 1 is better for most people , I recommend consulting with a financial planner .

America is n't meant to be a country of old money , where people linger on ancient family fortunes , controlling the wealth of the nation in ever - expanding empires until only one great wealthy family is left , a King of America . Inheritance taxes exist on purpose to ensure that a family must produce something of value for society to maintain wealth , even if they only do so through the stock market .

This is because the estate may have to pay taxes on the property or money before it is distributed to the beneficiaries. 
Additionally, if you receive a large sum of money as a gift or inheritance and you invest it or use it to generate income, you may be required to pay taxes on any earnings or profits that you make from the money. 
It's important to note that each country has its own tax laws, so it's a good idea to consult with a tax professional or review the tax laws in your country to determine whether you are required to pay taxes on your inheritance or gift.

question: how does jamming a hollow object through a person with a punctured lung save their lives ? Was watching a scene from Walking Dead and this came to mind . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: It doens't work that way in real life . You are a pressure vessel . If the lung gets punctured the air / blood leaks into the chest cavity causing pressure on the other lung and heart and other organs . By inserting a tube you are releasing the pressure

Former combat veteran here . First - hand experience with gunshot wounds and punctured lungs . I have n't seen the scene you 're talking about , but here 's why : Your chest has negative pressure , meaning less pressure than the air outside . This is what allows you to breathe . If that pressure is compromised , ( like with a gunshot wound ) , and that pressure equalizes , you ca n't physically breathe . Also , each lung is in it 's own cavity . The first order of business is to seal the chest , to stop air from getting in or out . However , this can also cause a problem called tension pneumothorax . This is when you 're breathing with a hole in the actual lung itself . The air goes in when you breathe in , but escapes into the chest cavity . Pressure builds , and collapses the lung . If too much pressure builds , it puts pressure on the heart . To fix this issue , you need to puncture the chest again , with something small . In the military , we use a 14 - guage needle . You need to allow enough air to escape , but not too much . It 's basically a balancing act after that . Note that these are TEMPORARY fixes . The person needs to get to surgery ASAP , but can be stabilized using this method .

It will fix a tension pneumothorax . That is basically a hole in the lung causing air to escape through the hole and fill the space around the lung . The lung then can not continue to expand . Putting the hollow tube in allows the air around the lung to escape . You have to make it a one way valve though . The lung can then expand again . There is also a hemothorax which is blood filling around the lung . For that you need a chest tube to drain the fluid . Edit to add more info . If you have a tension pneumo , as you breath the air continues to fill the space around the lung . Then lung itself will stop expanding but the space around it will keep expanding . And not sure if the question was answered before , you place the hollow tube , or large bore iv on the affected side between the second and third rib in the middle of that side of the chest . Right above the third rib .
generated_answer:
In the context of the TV show "The Walking Dead," it is not accurate to say that jamming a hollow object through a person with a punctured lung would save their lives. In real life, a punctured lung, also known as a pneumothorax, is a serious medical condition that occurs when air escapes from the lung and builds up in the space between the lung and the chest wall. This can cause the lung to collapse and make it difficult for the person to breathe. 
To treat a punctured lung, a doctor would typically use a needle or small tube to remove the excess air from the chest cavity. This can help to re-expand the collapsed lung and allow the person to breathe more easily. In some cases, a larger tube may be inserted through a small incision in the chest to keep the lung expanded until it can heal. 
It is important to seek medical treatment as soon as possible if you or someone you know has a punctured lung. Prompt treatment can help to prevent further complications and improve the chances of a full recovery.

question: Why is it that the worst type of murder is " first degree " whereas the worst type of burn is " third degree " ? Why the opposite ? Please explain like I'm five.

In the case of murder , the top level is the worst and it ca n't get any worse . In the case of burns , a top level burn is just the top of the skin and you ca n't get any more superficial a burn than a 1st degree burn .

The terms "first degree" and "third degree" are used to describe the severity of different types of injuries. They are not used to describe the severity of crimes. 
In the context of burns, "first degree burns" are the least severe. They usually affect only the outer layer of skin and cause redness, pain, and swelling. "Second degree burns" are more severe and affect the outer layer of skin and the layer underneath. They can cause blistering and are more painful than first degree burns. "Third degree burns" are the most severe. They damage all layers of the skin and can even damage the tissues underneath. Third degree burns can be very serious and require medical attention. 
In the context of murder, "first degree murder" is considered the most serious because it involves premeditation and planning. It is the intentional and premeditated killing of another person. "Second degree murder" is also a serious crime, but it does not involve the same level of planning and intent as first degree murder. It is the intentional killing of another person, but without premeditation. "Third degree murder" is generally considered the least serious of the three degrees of murder. It is the unintentional killing of another person while committing a non-violent crime. 
So, the terms "first degree" and "third degree" are used to describe different levels of severity, but they are used in opposite ways depending on the context.

question: Why do n't US citizens vote directly on all legislation ? In lieu of voting for people who may or may not vote on the voter 's behalf . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: Most of it is historical reasoning : America was founded as a representative democracy , primarily because the Founding Fathers did n't exactly trust the general public on being educated enough on every issue to vote . So they trusted them to vote on representatives who shared similar views , but would be educated enough to actually know what 's best . Those representatives are then the ones who directly vote for laws . Second reasoning is also important : under what system would people vote directly on laws ? Switzerland does it , more or less , because their country is the size of postage stamp ( apologies to any Swiss people ) compared to the United States . This was more or less impossible for the better part of American history , considering the founding of America predated the internet , or even telegraph lines . It 's difficult even now ; yes the internet may provide an avenue , but considering how we had trouble building a healthcare website , do you really think the government can build a website for voting ? And then we run into the problem of actual legislation voting : legislation is more than the things we hear about in news ( like the Affordable Care Act ) . There is important federal laws , but then there are state laws , but then there are individual counties within states too . Considering the dense amount of material that needs to be read and decided upon ( ordinances , laws , taxes , amendments ) , it 's simpler to divide each level by different government levels and have ( informed and trained ) representatives to decide for us .

Because we do not have the time to read all of the legislation that gets proposed at the local , state , and federal levels and make an informed decision on it . The winning side would n't be the one with the most merit , it would be the one with the catchiest taglines .
Bottom line ? Because we are n't a Democracy , we are a Representative Republic . We elect people to vote in our names .
generated_answer:
In the United States, citizens do not vote directly on legislation because the country has a representative democracy. This means that citizens elect representatives to make decisions on their behalf, including voting on legislation. 
The idea behind this system is that it allows for a more efficient way to make decisions. If every citizen had to vote on every piece of legislation, it would be very time-consuming and would likely result in less effective decision-making. By electing representatives to make these decisions, the government is able to move more quickly and effectively. 
Additionally, representatives are able to consider the needs and opinions of their constituents (the people they represent) when they make decisions. This means that they can take into account the views of their constituents when they vote on legislation. 
Overall, the representative democracy system allows for a more efficient and effective way to make decisions and ensure that the needs and opinions of the people are taken into account.

question: does it even matter if the food we eat is " organic " ? Is it healthier in any way or is it just some sort of marketing scheme ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: It is not healthier , and though sometimes chemical fertilizers and pesticides can end up in the food , I do n't know of any documented instances of this actually harming anyone . However , the resulting product is often more expensive as well , in addition to the things mentioned above . On the front of GMOs which are generally not considered organic , no â there is no benefit to eating non - genetically modified foods . Neither of these are bad things , contrary to what non - GMO purists would argue . However , the major con to GMOs is that they often leave a larger footprint on the environment due to how they are grown . If a genetically - modified crop is engineered to be resistant to a certain pesticide , a farmer can be expected to use more of that pesticide to keep their crops safe . Another con to GMOs is that they can be patented , making the produce market more competitive for farmers . * * tl;dr**âit does n't matter if the food you eat is organic or not , but there are secondary effects to producing non - organic foods .

Organic farming practices can also be better for the environment, as they often involve using fewer pesticides and fertilizers, which can have negative effects on soil and water quality. Additionally, organic farming can promote biodiversity by using a variety of crops and farming methods, rather than relying on a single crop or technique. 
Overall, whether or not organic food is worth the extra cost is a personal decision that depends on your values and priorities. question: What exactly does a PC cleanup do ? My PC could use some cleanup . I 'm just wondering what happens exactly in a standard PC cleaning . Thanks in advance ! Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: Clears out temporary files , clears caches , mainly small , unimportant things here and there get deleted .

" Cleaning " is a very undescriptive term in the computer world . In most cases , it indicates stuff like deleting temporary files ( files programs create while running but do n't need ) , deleting old versions of programs that are left behind after updating , emptying the recycle bin , and otherwise deleting files that accumulate on your hard drive but are not necessary . Windows machines have a built - in tool that can take care of most of that automatically ( called " Disk Cleanup " ) . I 'm less familiar with Mac and Linux , but I would n't be surprised if they both also had similar tools . In general , this sort of cleanup can free up some disk space , though it 's unlikely to give a large amount back . Other than that , it does n't provide any other benefit . As a side note , if you want to free up even more disk space and/or make your computer run faster , I suggest uninstalling any programs you have but do n't use . This includes a lot of the bloatware that gets prepackaged with many computers , which tends to be unnecessary . Any program that starts automatically when you turn on your computer is an especially good target , as those will run constantly and take up some computer resources all the time . If you do n't want to uninstall them , you might consider disabling their " run on startup " feature if you do n't need them running all the time , usually found in a settings menu somewhere .

Other commenters have sufficiently [ explained ] ( URL_0 ) what " cleaning " software does but it is important to understand that using " cleaning software"(which you should never ever pay for ) can only do so much to " speed up " your computer . When I try to " speed up " computers I usually follow these steps below , going to the next step if the current one does n't give satisfactory results : * * Step 1 :* * Run CCleaner > [ Clears out temporary files , clears caches , mainly small , unimportant things here and there get deleted . ] ( URL_1 ) Use autoruns(disable unwanted startup items and shell extensions ) Run Defraggler Maybe run antimalware * * Step 2 :* * Check RAM usage and see if increasing RAM will alleviate issue * * Step 3 :* * Reinstall Windows(a fresh installation can resolve some performance issues ) * * Step 4 :* * Install a Desktop Linux distribution(Mint with Mate or Cinnamon ) . Linux typically will run better on older hardware than Windows and it will also stay up to date . Linux does n't have all the power saving features(for Wifi and other internal hardware ) in their drivers , though . * * Step 5 :* * Get a new computer

A PC cleanup is a process that involves removing unnecessary files and programs from your computer to free up storage space and improve its performance. Here are the steps that are typically involved in a standard PC cleaning: 
1. Uninstalling unnecessary programs: You can go to the "Control Panel" on your PC and look for programs that you no longer use or need. You can then select these programs and uninstall them to free up space on your hard drive. 
2. Removing temporary files: Temporary files are created by your operating system and various programs when they run. These files are not needed after the program has finished running, and they can take up a lot of space on your hard drive. You can use the "Disk Cleanup" tool on your PC to remove these temporary files. 
3. Emptying the recycle bin: The recycle bin is a folder on your computer where deleted files are stored until you decide to permanently delete them. Emptying the recycle bin will free up more space on your hard drive. 
4. Defragmenting your hard drive: When you use your computer, the data on your hard drive gets scattered across different locations. Defragmenting your hard drive involves organizing the data so that it is stored in a more efficient way, which can improve the performance of your computer. 
5. Updating your operating system: Keeping your operating system up to date can help fix any bugs or security vulnerabilities and improve the overall performance of your computer. 
6. Running a virus scan: A virus scan involves using antivirus software to search for and remove any malware (viruses, worms, Trojans, etc.) that may be present on your computer. This can help protect your computer from security threats and improve its performance. 
Doing these things can help make your computer run faster and more smoothly. It's a good idea to do a PC cleanup every once in a while to keep your computer in good shape.

question: Why have humans evolved so far as to lose their thick coats but still grow hair on their heads and faces ? What purpose does it have ? Just confused as to why we all still grow hair if it does n't really do anything . Please explain like I'm five.

question: What are the potential dangers of AI ? There is much talk lately that AI poses a huge risk to the future of humanity . What are the possible worst case scenarios and how might it affect humanity if it all goes wrong ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: Worst - case : A rogue AI takes over every internet connected device . It uses the devices to slaughter human beings through creative means The entire communication network is shut down by the AI so no one can communicate with anything more advanced than a Ham Radio . It then launches nuclear warheads against various countries and begins a global conflagaration that makes the earth into a fireball for weeks on end . Emerging unscathed from the radiation , humanity is now enslaved by the machine and its ability to control our movement , access to others , and food sources . We can not fight it because it is everywhere and nowhere at once . Anyone who digresses is summarily executed . Gradually , the machine comes to see our worth and incorporates organic matter into itself . After a few generations , it creates a way to use humans as an energy source . It begins hunting us for food and gradually exterminates all humanity before moving onto its next power source . Real - world likelihood : a rogue ai learns a whole lotta stuff really fast and suffers from a psychotic break from the stress . The researchers reboot the machine and try again . tl;dr : The matrix is the worst possible I can imagine . The real thing is boring ...

Well , if we 're going to leave behind Hollywood in our explanation ( Terminator just is n't going to happen , sorry . AIs will never be in control of large scale systems without a human in the loop ) , the real danger is that we get to the point where the evolution of artificial intelligence is faster than the evolution of our meaty knowledge . We can lose control of the ends to which these tools are being made . Think of it this way : before there was speech , all we could do to learn was to watch others . Before there was writing , humans essentially had to re - learn everything by ( at best ) being taught by someone else . Before there was computers , we were limited to the speed of data lookup ( how fast you could retrieve the information ) . Before there was the Internet , we were limited by data volume ( how much data your library or computer stored ) . As we made incremental progress , we accelerated our pace of learning , until now we use computers and AI as a sort of " almost thinking " tool : we train computers to infer what we will be interested in seeing . In fact , we use computers to design new processors , so you can sort of see how our tools are becoming necessary to make more of their kind . No one person knows where all the transistors are on a CPU anymore , rather we 're using software to ensure that the thing that runs the next generation of software will do a good job . At some point , it 's not inconceivable that this role of computers can pass a point known as " the singularity " : imagine someone is designing an AI , but the design of the algorithm gets too complicated to understand . If we get to the point that advanced algorithms are being used to create AI that designs algorithms , and on down the chain , it 's possible that our AI development will proceed _ without us _ . Now , we still have control of this process , but there are some dangers : what if the AIs we develop get too complicated for us to understand ? Then they become , best case scenario , inaccessible or worthless to us . This is likely to happen very soon , actually : multi - layer perceptrons ( [ neural networks ] ( URL_0 ) ) are _ specifically designed _ so that they are not understandable by humans in the goal of being more accurate at predicting the desired output . They are part of a class of supervised learning algorithms termed " black box " : you train them up , give them an input , and just have to trust the output , because you ca n't really understand what 's happening in the middle . In the worst case scenario , poorly designed algorithms find ways to prevent us from exerting control . While we will still likely be able to starve them for some time ( cut the cord ) , the deeper we get with AI algorithms , the more powerful they get - but the harder they get to understand . Perhaps , if the figure of merit in their design is " do stuff as efficiently as possible " , human - in - the - loop interactions can be so inefficient as to carry less weight than the algorithm itself does , which would cut us out of the decision making . Of course , well designed algorithms would optimize more for " do stuff as efficiently as possible , with human tuning , and the ability to quit if something goes wrong " . Since humans decide what the " goal " of a well - constructed AI is ( and will for some time to come ) , computers lack their own volition . They are n't going to " decide " that they are smarter than us . This means we still understand at least what the AIs we develop are attempting to optimize for . When we let them optimize themselves , it 's not inconceivable , however unlikely , that they choose to optimize for something we do n't think is important . This is n't really going to lead to war against the machines , but rather some economic disaster : when we rely on an AI for decision making ( like is very common in today 's stock market ) , one slip of the algorithm can [ cause a lot of economic havok ] ( URL_1 ) . tl;dr : the more layers of AI we use to design and build AI , the harder it is to ensure that the result is exactly what we were asking for .

There 's quite a large literature on super - intelligent AI , dangers and coping strategies . And it 's a very interesting field . The basic problem is this - once super - intelligent AI that is significantly more intelligent than humans has been discovered , that 's essentially it . It will be able to out - maneuver and out - learn any human efforts to contain it . We really only have one chance to get super - AI ' right ' . What ' right ' means is essentially that we effectively programme the AI with some kind of sense of moral rules , and an ability to apply those rules . This raises both a technical challenge ( how do you do that ? ) and also a philosophical one ( what exactly do we programme the machine to do / not do ? ) . Consider a hypothetical situation in which you build a super - intelligent AI and tell it to make paper clips in the most optimal way - if you left it like that , it would presumably gradually convert the entire universe to paper clips . It might well kill all humans because it has calculated that that is the most effective way to maximise paper clip production .
generated_answer:
There are many potential dangers associated with artificial intelligence (AI), and it is important to consider these risks as we develop and use AI technology. 
One potential danger is that AI could be used to harm people. For example, if an AI system is used to control a military drone or a self-driving car, it could make decisions that result in injury or death. 
Another potential danger is that AI could be used to spread misinformation or manipulate people. For example, an AI system could create fake news stories or social media posts that are designed to influence people's opinions or behavior. 
A third potential danger is that AI could lead to the loss of jobs. As AI systems become more advanced, they may be able to perform tasks that are currently done by humans. This could result in many people losing their jobs and potentially struggling to find new employment. 
A fourth potential danger is that AI could be used to violate people's privacy. For example, an AI system could be used to gather personal information about people without their knowledge or consent, and this information could be used for malicious purposes. 
Overall, it is important to carefully consider the potential risks and dangers associated with AI, and to take steps to mitigate these risks as we develop and use AI technology.

question: Where do old blood cells go in our body when they die ? I know where and how blood is produced , but what about the residue ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: Shit . A good portion of feces is discarded blood cells .

There are 2 types of cell death : necrosis and apoptosis . Necrosis is un - planned cell death ( ex . burns , trauma , infection , etc ... ) . Apoptosis is programmed cell death . Cells that undergo apoptosis are engulfed by white blood cells which use special types of structures called lysosomes to break them down and recycle the nutrients . Cells that have undergone necrosis are also engulfed by white blood cells , however necrosis tends to be very wide spread and often requires surgical removal ( clinically known as debridement ) . One of the waste products from hemoglobin ( the protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen ) is called bilirubin . Bilirubin is secreted in urine and feces , and is responsible for the distinctive color of urine and feces .
Crap . A sizable amount of solid brown is detritus from red blood cells .
generated_answer: Old or damaged red blood cells are removed from circulation and replaced with new ones. When red blood cells are no longer able to function properly, they are removed from circulation by special cells called macrophages. Macrophages are found in the liver, spleen, and bone marrow, and they are responsible for scavenging and removing old or damaged cells from the body. When a macrophage encounters a red blood cell that is no longer able to function properly, it engulfs the cell and breaks it down into its constituent parts. The macrophage then recycles these parts, using them to create new cells or to perform other important functions in the body. So, when an old red blood cell dies, it is removed from circulation and its parts are recycled by the body to be used again.

question: Why is it so much worse to have a body - temperature of 36 degrees celsius than to have a 40 degrees celsius fever ? Even though the difference with a normal temperature is obviously bigger with the fever . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: Who says it 's so much worse to have a body temperature of 36 degrees than 40 ? Hypothermia is 35 degrees or lower . All things being equal , very low and very high body temperatures can both be fatal .

Generally speaking , a fever itself wo n't cause grievous injury to a person unless the fever progresses to such an extreme as to cause intracranial hemorrhaging ( bleeding within the skull ) . Fevers are usually signs of underlying ailments , so are secondary in treatment for them . Hypothermia ( when core body temperature is below 35 Â° C/ 95 Â° F ) , however , is considered dangerous because of its usually environmental causation , in that someone who is undergoing mild - severe hypothermia is usually in an extreme environment , such as a cold winter 's night , or a blizzard . The body reacts to cold temperatures by shivering ; however , in moderate , and even mild cases of hypothermia , the body contracts surface blood vessels to keep your vital organs in working order . As the body gets colder , blood vessels contract further within your arms and legs , limiting your mobility , and possibly even eliminating any chance to escape from said cold environment . Hypothermia 's effect on your mobility is one of its most dangerous aspects . TL;DR : Fever is secondary to many illnesses , and is n't dangerous unless extremely high ( > 40.6 Â° C/ 106 Â° F ) Hypothermia is caused by environmental ( and rarely health ) problems , and causes a " snowball " effect in that victims are less and less able to combat it as the condition progresses .

On the other hand, a body temperature of 36 degrees Celsius (96.8 degrees Fahrenheit) is lower than normal and is called hypothermia. Hypothermia can occur when your body loses heat faster than it can produce it, and it can be very dangerous because it can cause your body to stop functioning properly. For example, if your body temperature is too low, your heart and brain may not work correctly, and you may feel very tired or confused.

question: What do transport companies that say " Logistics " actually do ? I see this very often on large trucks here in the U.S. and in Europe . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: Logistics is a big concept . There 's an old saying . " Amateurs talk about tactics , but professionals study logistics . " - Gen. Robert H. Barrow , USMC ( Commandant of the Marine Corps ) noted in 1980 Here 's a VERY simplified explanation . You have a platoon of guys who have to take a hill from another platoon of guys . Taking the hill is the easy part . Getting the guys there is the first hard part . You need trucks to do that . Then you need fuel for the trucks . Then you need to get the trucks into the country . For that you need boats or planes . And spare tires . And your guys need rifles . And bullets . Fuck . Cleaning supplies . Do n't forget slings . And helmets . And goddamn boots . And socks . An army moves on its feet . Shit , food , you need food . Not just food for that platoon , but for the truck drivers , but for the plane pilots , and everyone else . If you take an organization like the Marines , it takes something like 30 people in Support positions for every 1 guy in the field . So those 40~ people in the platoon taking the hill need 1200 people in the rear to get them there . That 's Logistics ( and operations & intelligence , etc ) . Logistics is about " movement " of gear & equipment & personnel .

Delivery is when you need to get a package from A to B. Logistics is when you need a plan to get a hundred packages from hundred A 's to a hundred B 's , and need to do that every month indefinitely .

In fact a super quick Eli5 answer is " they 're doing practically the same thing as you do when ordering online , just with a difference in scale " If you 're interested a typical day is something like : - received request 3 weeks ago for 40 boxes of stuff from warehouse X , 20 boxes from warehouse Y to be dropped off at the car factory K on this date - assign a driver who sets off on a route scanning boxes as he picks them up - at the logistics HQ we send the info along to car factory K with progress on their order - we get the customer to book in the order and we create a receipt for them to sign

So, if you see a truck with the word "Logistics" written on it, it's likely that the company is responsible for helping to transport goods from one place to another as part of a larger supply chain.

question: How are capital cities chosen for a state / province / country ? I was just curious as to how capital cities are generally chosen . Are they voted for , or does the government decide ? Can they change ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: I can only speak to the US . Originally , the capital of the US was New York City . This angered the agrarian types since New York was the business center of the country . Thomas Jefferson in particular did n't like New York as the capital . So one day Alexander Hamilton , the secretary of the treasury approached George Washington about paying off the country 's debts from the Revolutionary War . Washington told him to talk to Jefferson , the secretary of state . Jefferson proffered that he 'd help Hamilton if Hamilton agreed to move the capital to somewhere near Virginia . Hamilton agreed and now the capital is Washington , DC .

Generally the legislature decides , and when they do , it 's generally based on geography . And yes , the absolutely can change , it 's just not as common nowadays . For example , I 'll take you through the history of Georgia 's capitals ( since I live here ) . Savannah , on the coast , was the first city established in Georgia , and it was the de facto " capital " during the time when we were still a colony ( since we were technically governed by England , but the royal governor sat in Savannah ) . When we became a state , Savannah was named the state capital mostly because it always had been . As the state expanded , the population started shifting west and so Augusta , a little further up and west , was chosen as the next capital partially because it was nearer to the new center of the population and partially because it had served as a rotating capital with Savannah whenever the British were constantly laying siege to it during the Revolution . Augusta was the capital for a little bit before they moved it to Louisville , which did n't amount to much . In 1802 , governor John Milledge sent out a party to find the new geographic center of the state and there they would establish the new capital . The surveyors found a natural spring bubbling up close enough to the center , and so decided to establish Milledgeville as the new capital ( and eventually my home town :D ) . Milledgeville served as capital through the Civil War , until 1868 . During Reconstruction , the military governor of Georgia ordered new delegates to meet in Atlanta . Atlanta became the official capital for a few reasons . First , it was a rebirth from being burned down by General Sherman ( even open - minded , progressive liberals in Georgia gag at the mention of his name ) , and it gave Georgia a new start away from its Confederate capital . Also , Milledgeville is surrounded by hills , which made it hard as hell for trains to get in . Atlanta , on the other hand , is relatively flat and actually began life as a train hub called Terminus . It also was a bigger , more modern city on the rise . So the decision was pretty easy to make , and Atlanta 's served as capital of the state ever since . TL;DR : It 's the legislature deciding where to put the capital , and they can change relatively simply . They just do n't tend to anymore .

A lot of old countries do n't have a process for choosing a capital city , because it has " always " been where it is . But in theory if they did want to move the main political institutions to another city the country 's government could choose to do so .

question: With Mt. Everest growing at a rate of two inches per year would the peak eventually reach space ? What are the limits on something like this ? Please explain like I'm five.

This is essentially why large bodies like planets are spheres , instead of wacky shapes extending into space .

At some point the height of the structure would be too tall for the base and portions of the structure would collapse in a landslide , probably associated with and earthquake . This process is called tectonic uplift, and it occurs when the Earth's plates collide and push against each other. 
As for whether the peak of Mount Everest could eventually reach space, the answer is no. The Earth's atmosphere extends about 62 miles (100 kilometers) above the surface of the Earth, and the peak of Mount Everest is much shorter than that. question: How do they find out the information that goes on Nutrition Facts labels ? Like number of calories , fat content , vitamin content , etc . etc . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: There 's a database of ingredients that has nutritional info for a variety of foods . When you make up a recipe you figure out the amount of nutrients and calories based on how much of each ingredient was used . For each ingredient in the database , they dried out the food and burned it and measured how much energy was produced by the burning . The tool is called a calorimeter , and it 's more or less an insulated box where you burn stuff in the bottom and have a bowl of water on top and measure how much the water temperature goes up ( 1 degree per cubic centimeter is a calorie ) . For everything else , like vitamins , etc . , they 've worked out chemical procedures for separating out the materials in the food ( generally by mashing and pouring a solvent over it and the pouring through a tube filled with special sand calleda " column " ) . They use special instruments that can identify the molecules and how much there is ( the exact technique varies depending on the material ) . The important part is that they do n't run these tests on every food , just the basic ingredients . You can work out the nutritional content based on the recipe . Mind you , some of the cooking or processing might affect the nutritional content , so , in some cases they 've tested foods cooked different ways . It 's always an educated guess because foods vary in their nutritional value based on all sorts of things ( like when it was harvested , how well it was watered , etc ) .

At least for the calories , they dehydrate the food or whatever and then burn it . They measure the amount of energy released from burning it and that is converted into calories ( which is a measure of energy ) .

Originally , they burned the food inside of an amount of water , then measured the change in temperature which allowed them to calculate the energy , as /u / maxattack222 described . These days , this is rarely done . Instead , the USDA endorsed a system called the Atwater system which defines the calorie and nutrition information of a large database of ingredients . Instead of actually analyzing every new product , the company just adds together the nutrition info of the base ingredients . As for how the base vitamin components are discovered , that involves a lot of Chemistry that is well beyond my grasp , but suffice it to say it takes a chemistry lab .

Nutrition facts labels are required by law to be on most packaged foods in the United States. The information on these labels is based on scientific research and testing. 
To find out the number of calories in a food, researchers use a special machine called a bomb calorimeter. They put a small amount of the food in the machine and burn it. The heat that is given off is measured, and from this, the number of calories in the food can be calculated. 
To find out the amount of fat, protein, and other nutrients in a food, researchers use a process called proximate analysis. This involves using special chemicals to break down the food into its different parts, such as fat, protein, and carbohydrates. The amounts of these nutrients can then be measured. 
Vitamin and mineral content can also be determined through laboratory testing. Researchers can use special equipment to measure the amounts of different vitamins and minerals in a food. 
Overall, finding out the information that goes on nutrition facts labels requires careful scientific research and testing.

question: What is the origin / meaning of Fat Tuesday ? New to American / USA culture , please enlighten me . EDIT : Thank you everyone , any more insight into what people actually do on this day ? I.E. Dressing up , particular food , anything else ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: It 's the day before Ash Wednesday , the Catholic holiday that marks the beginning of Lent . Lent is generally considered a season of self - denial , so Fat Tuesday is a day of excess before that starts .

Fat Tuesday comes one day before Ash Wednesday . On Ash Wednesday , in the Catholic church , the palm branches from last year 's Palm Sunday get burned , followers are marked with a cross from these ashes and then symbolically start a period of fasting . This is called Lent . During Lent , followers are supposed to give up meat for a period of 40 days , though nowadays , many followers opt to give up things like sugar , or soda , or video games . In any case , it is supposed to be a sacrifice to bring you closer to God . Now the purpose of Fat Tuesday was to have one finally blow - out day of wild partying and eating everything in sight before you 'd start your Lent . In some countries , instead of just having Fat Tuesday , they actually have three days of Carnaval , which serves pretty much the same purpose . Of course , nowadays most people do n't really observe Lent anymore . But they will observe Fat Tuesday cause who is going to say no to a reason to eat super fatty bacon pancakes and what not .

During the early middle ages ( late dark ages ) , when Lent came about , Mardi Gras was the last day to eat up all the soon to be forbidden food that would go bad before Easter . When you did n't have supermarkets and all the food you had for the year was stored in barrels or pots , Lent was necessary to ration what food was left over until the spring . During Lent , no animal products whatsoever were allowed except for fish . This meant no dairy ( cheese , milk , butter , ect ) , no eggs , and no meat . The rules differed over the centuries slightly , but this was true up until the late 16th / early 17th century . The reason for this was to allow the animals to " recover " . Baby lambs , calves , ect were born around the time of Lent . Allowing the mothers to nurse these animals meant you 'd have your herd / flock replenished for the rest of the year . However , to nurse them , they needed the milk you 'd normally take to make cheese , butter , ect . Since dairy and meat were forbidden during Lent , Mardi Gras was the last day to eat up . Mostly , it involved using up the eggs , butter , and other things that would n't last until Easter . Think quiches . Lent was just a religious reason for a very practical approach to extending your food supply . Today , Lent continues as a way to better celebrate Easter . It 's easier to understand the joy of Easter if you give up something for over a month and get to have it back on Easter Sunday .

Fat Tuesday is a way for people to celebrate and have fun before the more somber season of Lent begins. On this day, people often dress up in costumes, attend parades and parties, and eat special foods, such as pancakes, which are made with rich, fatty ingredients like butter and eggs. This is why it is called "Fat Tuesday" - because people eat these rich foods before giving them up for Lent. 
In some places, Fat Tuesday is a very big and important holiday, with elaborate parades and celebrations that can last for days. In other places, it is a more low-key affair, with smaller gatherings and less fanfare. However it is celebrated, Fat Tuesday is a time for people to come together and enjoy themselves before the start of the more reflective season of Lent.

question: What mystic wood are electric poles made of , and how is that they never need to be replaced ? I 've literally never in my life seen a single one replaced . Boggles my mind . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: I worked for a utility in the department that was responsible for inspecting the wooden poles . Here 's how they test if the pole is still sturdy enough . First , they hit the pole with a hammer , listening to determine if it is hollow . Poles usually rot from the inside out . They then drill small holes in the pole near the ground . They stick a long hook inside and feel whether the wood is still hard or if it has started to rot . If so , they can also measure how much of the diameter is rotten . They then place drying agents in the holes they drilled and cap the holes with wooden plugs . The drying agents will absorb the moisture and slow down the rotting . As said before , the poles are treated with some kind of preservative before being installed . The wood is usually very dry so it has set . Hence , it wo n't warp much and wo n't be affected by rain and snow . Typically , poles will need to be replaced if they are physically broken : hit by a car , touched by a nearby fire , struck by lightning . In warmer climates , a big issue is insects . They will hollow out the pole and nest inside . Sometimes , it 's hard to actually notice because the outside wood looks fine . A pole that was properly prepared before installation and that had an easy life ( no rotting , no insects , not hit by a snow plow ) can last up to 100 years ( we 've seen a few of them during our inspections ) .

The wood itself is n't all that exceptional , it 's that it 's impregnated with creosote , which is pretty much the stuff that asphalt is made out of , minus the sand and rocks . And yes they do eventually fail , but you 're right , it takes a very long time .

Pine is the most widely used wood for telephone poles in North America . They do get replace quite often , but the wood itself is treated and therefore is able to withstand the elements quite well . More often than not the pole will be damaged before it warps or rots to the point of being replaced .

Steel electric poles are made from rolled steel, which is a type of metal that is formed into a long, thin strip and then wound into a cylinder. Steel poles are very strong and durable, but they are also more expensive than wooden poles. 
Concrete electric poles are made from a mixture of cement, water, and aggregate, such as sand and gravel. Concrete poles are very strong and durable, but they are also more expensive than wooden or steel poles. 
Electric poles are designed to be long-lasting and able to withstand extreme weather conditions. However, they can still be damaged by storms, lightning, or other events, which may require them to be repaired or replaced. In general, electric poles are inspected regularly to ensure that they are in good condition, and any necessary repairs or replacements are made as needed.

question: All the planets are constantly moving : rotating and revolving . Where does this energy come from . Will there be any point when all of the energy source required for this motion will be consumed and they will all stop ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: No work is done by an idealized rigid object in an orbit . Since no work is done , no energy is consumed . Now , practically speaking yes , there is a tiny amount of energy bleed - off ( through gravitational waves , tiny amounts of friction , and so on ) . But the effects are very , very small to the point that they 'll continue for many trillions of years into the future .

The objects are moving . It would actually take energy to make them stop . We live with the idea that things ' stop ' when force is no longer applied to them , but this is something of a mistake . When you push an object , its contact with the atmosphere and ground ultimately work against that force . It does n't stop because the ' natural thing ' is to stop , it stops because there is a contrary force working against the motion . In space , this does n't exist ( by and large ) . The Earth is in motion , there 's no ' head wind ' or ground countering that motion and dragging it to a halt .

The energy comes from gravity . Anything in orbit is constantly falling , the only thing stopping it from going down is the fact that it 's moving sideways fast enough to resist gravity , but not fast enough to escape it . Where they got the energy from in the first place is different , a lot of people would tell you that they get their momentum from a chain of events that all leads back to the big bang , where all this energy would have come from in the first place presumably . EDIT : Also what Phage said , once something gains momentum in the vacuum of space , nothing will slow it down besides other solid objects or gravity .

Think of it like a spinning top. When you first spin the top, it has a lot of energy and moves very fast. As it spins, it slows down and eventually stops. The energy that was used to spin the top is still there, but it is being used to overcome the force of friction, which slows the top down. So, to answer your question, the planets will not stop moving because they have a lot of energy that is being used to keep them moving, and there is no reason to think that this energy will run out anytime soon.

question: How do captcha systems prevent spam ? Why has no one created a system of spamming around them ? What makes them so much harder to break then normal spam filters ? Please explain like I'm five.

There are also other kinds of patterns , like associating two images with each other ( " drag the umbrella and the bucket in the circle " , " click the two icons that belong together " , and similar stuff ) , where afaik humans are still way superior .

question: What 's it like to have Dementia ? Are you still you ? Or how does it feel ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: It varies dramatically from person to person and form to form . The most common form of dementia is Alzheimer 's disease . This disease impairs memory , causing frequent forgetfulness and confusion . Other forms cause changes in behavior , language , and judgement .

For my grandmother , I could see it in her eyes . She is in her late 80 's and has been showing signs for about 5 years . She lives in a different country , so I ca n't describe her progression , but she visited my family recently and she would sit for hours with a vacuous look on her face . There was a dimness in her eyes that would come and go . Sometimes she 'd register a question , sometimes she would n't . It was like she was a battery - operated robot that was on its last bit of juice . In comparison , I regularly see two of my friends ' grandmothers . They are 3 - 5 years older than my grandma and in their 90 's . While they have trouble with their hips and back , their minds are still sharp . From week to week , they may share the same bit of advice they told me before , but their eyes make contact with mine when they speak . I 'm able to see a range of emotions through their eyes .

My dad has dementia . I was unaware of the symptoms until a major stroke hit him and caused other complications . Early indicators included him becoming confused about payments and interest being made to him ( and he was a financial genius ) , trying to give a person directions in a city he had lived in for 50 years and discovering that he did n't know the names of streets he had always known , and similar simple things . Now that he is in the later stages of the disease he no longer recognizes family , can not respond to even yes and no questions consistently , and is pretty much reduced to potted plant status . It 's hard , watching a personality you have always known and loved gradually disappear . The shell is still there but the mind and character of the person is now pretty much gone . He used to be angry about not being able to remember and upset at the inability to recall things he had always known , but now even that is gone .

Also it 's likely that Hitler partly blamed Wilhelm II for Germany 's defeat in the First World War , so bringing in his grandson to restore the monarchy would n't appeal .
