Had the exact same issues , i fixed this by walking around room or my house while reading and would often read aloud . It made it so I never got tired and could actually finish a damn book .
Probably concentration . Switching tasks stimulates different parts of the brain
generated_answer:
It's normal to feel tired after engaging in activities that require mental effort, like reading a book or driving for a long period of time. These activities can be mentally exhausting, which can cause fatigue and make you feel tired. 
When you stop the activity and take a break, your body and mind have a chance to rest and recover. This can help you feel more alert and awake. 
It's also possible that you may be feeling tired due to other factors, such as not getting enough sleep or being dehydrated. It's important to make sure you are getting enough rest and staying hydrated to help prevent fatigue.

question: Why are n't animals given a vasectomy instead of being neutered ? It seems like it would be much more humane Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: Most of the time it 's to do with behavioral modification . A vasectomy does n't remove any of the male hormones or change behavior at all . Intact male dogs will go wandering looking for females in heat , and also tend to be a little more argumentative . It also can be hard to keep weight on intact males . Dogs " tie " during sex , and can be severely injured if one partner breaks the tie . And of course all animals get STDs . Testicular cancer is also extremely common in intact males . Toms are much more likely to get in fights , and they will spray everything in your house . Stallions can be aggressive , very mouthy , and difficult to handle . They also tend not to grow as tall as geldings . Also difficult to keep weight on them , and need to be housed completely separately from mares . Mares will kick the crap out of stallions , so gelding them is a good way to avoid injury all around . Testosterone also ruins the taste and smell of meat , particularly pork . Meat animals are castrated early to maintain the value of the meat .
becuase many of the animals that are neutered are neutred to change behaviour that would not change with a vasectomy and to prevent health probelsms from later devolpoing .

Neuters are actually very simple and easy procedures that take ( typically ) 10 - 20 minutes . That s not to say there is n't a risk , as there always is with surgery and incisions , but honestly the positives vastly outweigh the possible negatives . What is inhumane about it ? - painless , safe procedure undertaken by a doctor and nurse in a clinical setting similar to what a human experiences while they are in the operating room ( e.g. anesthesia , monitoring , sterile , aftercare ) - medication given to manage the pain at home - follow up check - ups to insure that there is no infection and that the pet is healing well - improved behaviour on part of the pet , safer for other animals that ay interact with your pet and safer for females ( spayed or unspayed ) - less unwanted pups or kittens starving to death behind dumpsters , or being euthanized in overflowing shelters - decreased risk of developing testicular cancer later in the animals life , potentially save you thousands of dollars - costs way less than similar human procedures , with similar quality of care , despite the extremely high overhead costs of running a veterinary clinic Where is the downside ?
generated_answer:
There are a few reasons why veterinarians usually prefer to neuter animals (i.e., remove their testicles) rather than performing a vasectomy (i.e., cutting the vas deferens to block the flow of sperm). 
First, a vasectomy is a more complicated and invasive surgery than neutering. It requires a higher level of surgical skill and specialized equipment, and the recovery period is typically longer for the animal. In contrast, neutering is a relatively straightforward procedure that can often be performed under general anesthesia in a veterinary clinic setting. 
Second, neutering is more effective at reducing unwanted behaviors in animals, such as aggression, marking territory, and roaming. This is because neutering removes the source of hormones (testosterone) that contribute to these behaviors. A vasectomy, on the other hand, only blocks the flow of sperm and does not significantly reduce the production of hormones. 
Finally, neutering is a more cost-effective option for pet owners, as it is generally less expensive than a vasectomy. 
Overall, while a vasectomy might seem more humane in theory, in practice it is usually a less practical and effective option for preventing unwanted pregnancies and modifying behavior in animals.

question: Why do we have both a North and a True North ? My iPhone shows if I want to see the North or the True North . What is the difference between both and why do both exist ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: True North is what we see at the top in a standard map . It is the top of the world . These will follow the meridians . The " other " North is Magnetic North , and has slowly been shifting away from True North an is now in the Arctic Ocean .
There 's true north , which is defined by the axis Earth spins on , and there 's magnetic north , which is defined by the orientation of Earth 's magnetic field . They do n't quite line up .
True North is the axis about which the Earth rotates . Magnetic North is the point near True North that represents one of the magnetic poles our planets molten core creates as it rotates .
generated_answer:
Great question! The Earth is not a perfect sphere, it is actually slightly flattened at the poles and bulges at the equator. This means that the Earth's rotational axis, which is an imaginary line that runs through the center of the Earth and around which the Earth rotates, is not perpendicular to the surface of the Earth. Instead, it is tilted by about 23.5 degrees. 
The North Pole is the point on the Earth's surface that is directly above the Earth's rotational axis. This is the point that is used to define the direction of "north." 
True North, on the other hand, is the direction of the North Pole relative to the surface of the Earth. It is the direction that a compass needle points towards, which is not the same as the direction of the North Pole. This is because the Earth's magnetic field causes the compass needle to be attracted to the Earth's magnetic north pole, which is not exactly the same as the Earth's rotational north pole. 
So, to sum it up: "North" is the direction that is defined by the Earth's rotational axis, and "True North" is the direction that a compass needle points towards due to the Earth's magnetic field. Both of these directions are important for different reasons, and that's why we have both of them.

question: How and why did Global Warming get changed to Climate Change ? Climate change always seemed so generic , since our climate is always changing . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: because a slight energy increese ( warming ) of our planet will cause a change in our climate . people heard the name " global warming " and assumed that it meant that everything would just get hotter and then dismissed it when we have cold winters TL , DR : " global warming " is misleading to the uninformed public

I think deniers usually blame the " warmists " for changing this and see it as yet another cop out excuse to keep the gravy train rolling when temperatures did n't increase in 16 years . In fact , I think climate scientists realised that AGW climate change is more complex than simply hotter temperatures .

Both terms have been used in scientific literature for decades and refer to different things . Global warming is simply the observation that the global climate is growing warmer on average . Climate change is that change in temperature plus all of the other changes that come along with it , including changes in precipitation , albedo , air and water circulation , etc . The change in common usage was actually due to Republican political strategist Frank Luntz who wrote in a memo to Republican candidates that they should use the phrase climate change rather than global warming in their addresses to the public because it sounded less scary . The exact quote : > We have spent the last seven years examining how best to communicate complicated ideas and controversial subjects . The terminology in the upcoming environmental debate needs refinement , starting with â global warming ââ and ending with " environmentalism , ââ It âs time for us to start talking about â climate change â instead of global warming and â conservation â instead of preservation . . > Climate change ââ is less frightening than â global warming ; â As one focus group participant noted , climate change â sounds like you âre going from Pittsburgh to Fort Lauderdale . â While global warming has catastrophic connotations attached to it , climate change suggests a more controllable and less emotional challenge . " URL_0
generated_answer:
Global warming and climate change are often used interchangeably, but they refer to slightly different things. 
Global warming refers to the increase in the average temperature of the Earth's atmosphere, especially at the surface, which has been occurring over the past century or so. The main cause of global warming is the burning of fossil fuels, such as coal and oil, which releases greenhouse gases into the atmosphere. These gases trap heat from the sun and cause the Earth's temperature to rise. 
Climate change, on the other hand, refers to the broader range of changes that are occurring in the Earth's climate, including not only the increase in temperature, but also changes in precipitation patterns, sea level, and other factors. Climate change can be caused by both natural and human factors, and it can have a range of impacts on the environment, including more frequent heatwaves, droughts, and extreme weather events like hurricanes and floods. 
So, to sum it up, global warming is a specific aspect of climate change, which is a broader term that encompasses a range of changes that are occurring in the Earth's climate.

question: Why do cars only have defroster grids in the rear window ? I am thinking it has something to do with what might happen if the windshield shattered , but it would be convenient a lot of the time . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: Rear window is far enough back that the lines of the defroster grid are not too distracting during the brief glances back drivers make during driving . Putting those lines in the front window would prove to be hazardous to many drivers by being visual distractions . This is the same reason LEO 's will issue tickets for driving with large cracks in your front windows , and that hanging stuff from your rear - view mirror is ticketable as well ( usually only happens if you 've ticked off the officer ) .

Most cars have their climate control system centralized in the front dashboard . It is easier to duct warm air to the front windshield than it is to pass the treated air back to the rear window since this would require lengths of tubes with turns and bends that present flow losses to the gas flow . So electrical grids are a better option for the rear windows .

The latest models do have defroster in the front . Ford for example has trademarked its heated windshield under the name " Quickclear " . So , its coming . Check [ this ] ( URL_0 ) for example . Plus , you do n't wanna look to / thru all those little wires .
generated_answer:
Cars only have defroster grids in the rear window because the front windshield is made of different material than the rear window. The front windshield is made of laminated safety glass, which is two layers of glass with a plastic layer in between. The laminated safety glass is designed to stay in one piece even if it cracks or breaks, so it doesn't need a defroster grid to help clear it. 
The rear window, on the other hand, is usually made of tempered glass, which is a type of glass that shatters into small pieces if it breaks. Tempered glass is used in the rear window because it is stronger and more durable than regular glass, but it is also more prone to fogging up or getting covered in condensation. That's why the rear window has a defroster grid, which is a grid of heating elements that help clear the window of fog or condensation. 
So, in short, cars have defroster grids in the rear window because it is made of a different type of glass that is more prone to fogging up, and because the front windshield is made of laminated safety glass that doesn't need a defroster grid.

question: When I need to pee , and I 'm standing there waiting , but nothing is coming out , what 's happening in my body that 's making me wait ? Shy pissers unite ! Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: You brain is good at knowing when the appropriate time to " go " is , so much so that it lets you be largely in charge of it . This happens because of 4 different types of nerves controlling the urinary mechanisms : Sensory ( afferent ) nerves , which tell you your bladder is full ; sympathetic ( " fight / flight " ) nerves which relax the bladder and keep the urinary sphincter tight ; parasympathetic ( " rest / digest " ) nerves which contract the bladder and relax said sphincter ; and somatic nerves ( that act on skeletal muscles , i.e. Muscles you can control voluntarily ) which let you initiate when to go . When you are in line at Fatty 's Pizza Shack , for instance , your sympathetic nervous system ( fight / flight ) is keeping that bladder sphincter tightly closed ( it does this without you even knowing it , much like you do n't need to consciously make your heart beat ) . Later , after drinking your extra large Floaty Shake , your bladder fills with urine , and sensory nerves alert you to this fact via stretch receptors on the bladder itself . As your bladder fills with more urine , the stretch sensors cause little contractions in the bladder which you feel as urges . When you finally feel like it 's a good time to pee on something , your somatic nerves signal your accessory muscles ( abdominals ) to assist with voiding ( a fancy word for micturition which is an even fancier word for urination ) , and your parasympathetic nerves ( rest / digest ) takes the hint and squeezes the bladder and relaxes your urinary sphincter . The result is pee happening . Several regions in the brain are also involved , mainly keeping you from peeing when you do n't want to pee . You can consciously keep from wetting yourself for quite a while , unless you have some sort of disease where nerves are damaged or the muscles in your bladder ( detrusor muscle and sphincters ) do n't cooperate . Incontinence = ca n't hold it in . Enuresis = bedwetting .
It 's the urinary sphincter not relaxing fast enough , probably due to shyness or tension . Some medications can affect the sphincter causing urinary retention .

I read on here somewhere , some post , about standing at the urinal , lots of dudes standing in line and it just wo nt release . This Redditor stated that doing math in your head releases the muscle or whatever it is that is clammed up due to self inflicted intimidation . Tried it and damn , it worked like a charm . 2 + 2=4 , 4 + 4=8 .. I think I made it to 64 and was whizzing full throttle . Go figure ... no pun intended .
generated_answer:
When you feel the urge to urinate, your body is sending a signal to your brain that your bladder is full and needs to be emptied. The bladder is a muscular sac in your pelvis that stores urine until it is ready to be expelled from the body. 
When you stand at the toilet and try to urinate, your brain sends a signal to the muscles in your pelvic area to relax, including the muscles that control the bladder. At the same time, the muscles in the wall of your bladder contract, pushing the urine out through the urethra (the tube that carries urine out of the body). 
Sometimes, when you try to urinate, the muscles in your pelvic area may not fully relax, or the muscles in the wall of your bladder may not contract strongly enough. This can make it difficult to start urinating, or to urinate as much as you normally would. This is more common in men, but it can happen to anyone. 
There are a few things you can try to help you urinate more easily when you're having difficulty: 
1. Take a deep breath and try to relax your muscles. 
2. Try massaging your lower abdomen or stomach area gently. 
3. Drink a glass of water or another fluid. This can help to increase the volume of urine in your bladder, making it easier to start urinating. 
4. Try going back to bed and waiting a little while longer. Sometimes, just waiting a few minutes can help your muscles relax enough to allow you to urinate. 
If you continue to have difficulty urinating, or if you have other symptoms such as pain or blood in your urine, you should speak with a healthcare provider. They can help to determine the cause of your symptoms and provide treatment if necessary.

question: Difference between isopropyl alcohol ( " rubbing alcohol " ) , ethyl alcohol , and methyl alcohol ? Edit : Thanks guys . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: Ethyl alcohol is the kind you drink . It is produced by yeast . . The yeast eat some kind of sugar or starch and turn it into carbon dioxide and alcohol . In wine the process is pretty simple â yeast eats the sugar in grape juice and creates alcohol . In whiskey , the alcohol is distilled to get the concentration higher . Ethanol that you purchase as a car fuel is the same kind of alcohol found in whiskey , but it has been distilled to the point where it is nearly pure alcohol ( as opposed to whiskey which is typically only 40 % alcohol and 60 % water ) . Methanol is sometimes found in windshield wiper fluid to keep it from freezing , and it is also used as the fuel for Champ cars and Indy cars . It is sometimes called wood alcohol because it used to be made from wood , but today its made from natural gas . Methanol is poisonous , and it is one of the chemicals that can be used to poison denatured alcohol . The chemical difference is how many carbon atoms there are .

They 're different chemicals . An alcohol is a string of carbon atoms that are bonded to hydrogen atoms everywhere except that there 's an ( OH ) in place of a hydrogen atom somewhere . Methanol is the simplest alcohol , consisting of just one carbon atom , 3 hydrogen atoms , and one ( OH ) group . Ethanol is basically the same as methanol , except it has two carbon atoms . Isopropyl alcohol has three carbons , but it 's a little different from methanol and ethanol . Instead of having the ( OH ) group at one end of the molecule , it has it sticking out of the middle . In terms of effects on the human body , they all do similar things . The problem with drinking methanol and isopropanol is that the stuff your body metabolizes them into is quite toxic and can cause a lot of bad stuff to happen . Fortunately , one way to treat overdoses of methanol and isopropanol by getting the person very drunk for a while . Your body prefers to metabolize ethanol over methanol and isopropanol , so staying drunk for a while allows you to get rid of the methanol or isopropanol by breathing , sweating , and urinating it out directly without being turned into bad stuff .

Methyl alcohol has one Carbon atom and one hydroxyl group ( -OH ) . Its chemical formula is CH3 - OH . It is aka " wood alcohol " as at one time it was obtained by wood distillation . It is poisonous to drink . It will give the similar mind - altering effects as ethanol ( ethyl alcohol ) , but it will eventually make you go blind . Ethyl alcohol has 2 carbon atoms and one hydroxyl group . Its chemical fomula is C2H5OH ( or CH3 - CH2 - OH ) . It is frequently obtained by the yeast - driven distillation of grains and fruits . It has mind altering effects , but can lead to other medical problems if use is frequent and chronic . It is also often used as a fuel additive . Isopropyl alcohol has 3 carbon atoms and one hydroxyl group , with the hydroxyl group attached to the middle carbon atom . Its chemical formula is C3H7OH ( or CH3 - CH(OH)-CH3 ) . It is poisonous to drink . It is used almost exclusively as an industrial solvent or as a medical disinfectant . They are all flammable to various degrees .
generated_answer:
Isopropyl alcohol, ethyl alcohol, and methyl alcohol are all types of alcohol, but they have some differences. 
Isopropyl alcohol, also known as rubbing alcohol, is a type of alcohol that is commonly used as a disinfectant. It is a clear, colorless liquid with a strong, sweet smell. It is often used to clean surfaces and to kill germs on the skin. 
Ethyl alcohol, also known as ethanol or grain alcohol, is a type of alcohol that is commonly found in alcoholic beverages like beer, wine, and liquor. It is also used as a solvent and in the production of personal care and cleaning products. Ethyl alcohol is a clear, colorless liquid with a sweet, fruity smell. 
Methyl alcohol, also known as methanol or wood alcohol, is a type of alcohol that is toxic and not suitable for consumption. It is sometimes used as an industrial solvent and in the production of chemicals. Methyl alcohol is a clear, colorless liquid with a strong, sweet smell. 
In summary, isopropyl alcohol is a type of alcohol that is used as a disinfectant, ethyl alcohol is a type of alcohol found in alcoholic beverages, and methyl alcohol is a toxic alcohol that is not suitable for consumption.

question: Sugar , is it worse for your teeth to have alot of sugar in one go or to spread it out over time ? Is there a limit to how much damage you can do to your teeth with sugar in one go ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: According to the dentists : It is worse to continually eat ( all foods , not just sugar ! ) during the day than to eat more during short periods . The reason for this is that your teeth needs to " rest " between the meals . This is also why dentists recommend that you wait 20 - 30 min after eating to brush your teeth , otherwise you hurt them instead of cleaning . * quick note though ! Dentists seem to be easily bribed to recommend things !

With your teeth I would n't be too worried about a binge of sugar , the long term effect of sugar ( and other carbs ) on your teeth would be worse than the occasional overdose . However in terms of your pancreas and insulin levels , a small amount of sugar ( and other carbs ) spread out is much better than just pounding sugar cubes .

To touch on what the periodontist said , if one is using proper brushing techniques , it wo n't matter [ too much ] , but there is still a difference . The short answer : sugar all at once is better . Your internal organs wo n't like it , but it 's better for your teeth . The long answer : Sugar , and the by products bacteria in your mouth produce from breaking it down , are acidic . The acid itself , while not beneficial , is n't the only cause of tooth decay in this instance . When your mouth 's PH is out of whack , this affects the rate of production and the effectiveness of the saliva your mouth produces . Why is this important ? Your saliva has something in it called hydroxyaptite that contains phosphate and calcium ions . The concentrations of these ions act as a buffer against tooth decay , but only when their presence in your saliva is at a high enough concentration . Guess what happens the more acidic your mouth becomes ? Its ability to hold hydroxyaptite decreases dramatically , leaving your mouth more vulnerable . So yes , sugar all at once is better . If you buy a Big Gulp soda and sip it over the course of three hours , you 're maintaining a low low PH in your mouth which will dramatically lower your saliva 's ability to fight tooth decay â moreso than if you 'd just drank the entire thing in 20 minutes .
generated_answer:
It's generally better for your teeth to have sugar in small amounts rather than all at once. That's because sugar can cause tooth decay, which is a process that happens when bacteria in your mouth use sugar from the foods you eat to make acids. These acids can attack your tooth enamel, which is the hard outer layer of your teeth. If the enamel gets weak or wears away, it can lead to cavities. 
When you eat or drink something with sugar in it, the bacteria in your mouth start making acid right away. The more sugar you eat or drink, the more acid they can make. So if you eat or drink a lot of sugar all at once, your teeth will be exposed to a lot of acid at once, which can be harmful. 
On the other hand, if you have small amounts of sugar throughout the day, your teeth will be exposed to acid for a longer period of time, but the amount of acid they're exposed to at any given moment will be smaller. This can be less harmful to your teeth. 
It's also important to remember to brush your teeth twice a day and floss once a day to help remove sugar and plaque from your teeth. Plaque is a sticky film of bacteria that can build up on your teeth and cause tooth decay. 
So, to sum up: it's better for your teeth to have sugar in small amounts rather than all at once, and it's important to brush and floss your teeth to help protect them from sugar and plaque.

There are several reasons why prescription drugs may be more expensive in the United States compared to other countries. 
One reason is that the prices of prescription drugs are often higher in the United States because the manufacturers of those drugs can charge more. These higher prices may be due to the high cost of researching and developing new drugs, as well as the cost of marketing and selling them. 
Another reason is that the government in the United States does not regulate the prices of prescription drugs as closely as it does in other countries. In other countries, the government may negotiate with drug manufacturers to get lower prices for prescription drugs, or it may regulate the prices of drugs to make them more affordable for people. So, to sum it up, prescription drugs may be more expensive in the United States because the manufacturers can charge more, the government does not regulate drug prices as closely, and the system for paying for drugs is complex.

question: Why do we vomit when we see or smell something that is disgusting or uncomfortable ? NSFW just in case . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: I saw an article once that suggested this is an evolutionary response . Imagine life in prehistoric times , or maybe going as far back as the common ancestor between apes and men . Nobody knows which plants are poisonous and which ones are safe to eat . A bunch of us are sitting around eating and someone gets violently ill due to being poisoned . If we 're all eating the same plant , it 's too late for the guy who got poisoned but it might not be too late for the others . Those who get grossed out and throw up stand a better chance of not getting poisoned . Evolution selected for the ones who puked .

I recalled reading this once in a BBC . It 's an evolutionary behaviour so to get rid of the harmful substance because it is assumed the particular being has already ingested the ' harmful substance '

Along with the idea that it is a reaction to poison and stuff as mentioned by others , it has also evolved to stop curious humans from eating rotting things filled with nasty bacteria ; a preventative measure . In prehistoric times , the person who reacted the worst to the smell of the rotting meat / veges would have been the least likely to eat it , and therefore the most likely to survive in that situation . Gradually , it was selected for more and more and here we are today . Animals with a more robust gut , like hyena 's and vultures have no problems with eating stuff that we would n't go near if we were promised all the money in the world .
generated_answer: Vomiting is a natural reflex that helps your body get rid of substances that are harmful or irritating to your stomach. When you see or smell something that is disgusting or uncomfortable, your brain sends a signal to your stomach to contract and push the contents of your stomach out through your mouth. This is known as vomiting. Vomiting can also be caused by other things, such as infections, food poisoning, or certain medications. It is your body's way of trying to get rid of something that is causing you discomfort or harm.

question: Why ca n't we prove climate change ? In other words , what 's so difficult that we ca n't present extremely obvious facts of information that people should not doubt ? Please explain like I'm five.

question: If cancer is just cells mutating and dividing without abandon , how does it cause the " rot " we see in later stages ? Title . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: The cancerous " rot " you show below is a result of necrosis where the tumor has grown so much that it no longer get nutrients and oxygen from the blood supply . The cells on the interior of the tumor die . There are two types of cell death : apopotosis , which is tightly regulated , and necrosis , which is unregulated . Unregulated dying , as is the case in tumor rot , causes a cell to release all of its contents onto neighboring cells , causing those cells to necrose as well . This usually results in the entire area to start decomposing , causing secondary bacterial infections and general gross - ness . This is part of the reason why people with necrotising fasciitis ( flesh eating disease ) have to get entire areas of necrosis removed , like arms or legs or whatever to prevent the rot from spreading . Fortunately , in humans cancer rarely gets so bad that you see that extent of rot . Usually the tumor is palpable and can be treated or removed before huge rotting occurs . Source : PhD in cancer metabolism .

If suddenly a bunny had a million little bunnies , they would eat all the carrots , and soon every single bunny would starve and be sad little bunnies .

question: Why do humans have different bloodtypes ? URL_0 This was interesting Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: If you 're looking for the anatomical reason , it deals with the Red Blood Cell surfaces . RBCs are the cells that contain hemoglobin , which act to pick up / drop Oxygen and Carbon Dioxide in the blood stream to metabolically support and " feed " all of the cells in your body . An antigen is a protein on the surface of a cell that acts as a " flag " for the immune system . RBCs in a certain person contain contain types of antigens . In reality , there are thousands of antigens present , but in terms of labeling RBCs , there are 3 important ones : A , B , and D ( Rh ) . A person with a certain antigen of these three would also have blood plasma ( surrounding liquid around RBCs ) containing antibodies ( bind to the antigens ) for the other blood types . For example , a person with Type A blood would have antigens for Type B and D Blood . This is why you ca n't give blood to a person of a different blood type because the antibodies will react with your antigens on your RBCs , causing clumping and apoptosis . The Rh antigen brings the + /- factor that you often see on blood types . If Rh ( D ) is present , the type is + and the plasma contains no Rh antibodies . If Rh is not present on the surface , the type is - and the plasma contains Rh antibodies . Effectively , these are the blood types : A+ : contains A , D antigens and B antibodies A- : contains A antigens and B , D antibodies B+ : contains B , D antigens and A antibodies B- : contains B antigens and A , D antibodies AB+ : contains A , B , D antigens and no antibodies AB- : contains A , B antigens and D antibodies O+ : contains D antigens , and A , B antibodies O- : contains no antigens , and A , B , D antibodies This would make O- the universal donor blood type because the blood cells contain no antigens for which a recipient 's antibodies could react with . AB+ is the universal recipient because it has no antibodies in the plasma that could react with a donor 's blood 's antigens .

question: How does rubber ground out electricity ? What is it about rubber of all materials that " neutralizes " electricity ? Does it actually neutralize the electricity or does something else happen ? Is there any other material that acts in the same manner ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: It does n't ground it . Rubber is an insulator . Electricity will always travel " the path of least resistance . " Rubber has a very high resistance , so electricity will go somewhere else to find ground .

Electricity is the flow of electrons . Without electron flow , there is no electricity . Metals and other conductors have very " free " electrons - metals actually have delocalized electrons that travel freely between atoms . Rubber is an organic polymer - a repeating chain / mesh of non - metal atoms which hold on to their electrons much more tightly . While covalent bonds are relatively free electrons , and some functional groups have a few delocalized electrons ( phenyls , enols , etc ) , the amount of electron flow ( capacity ) is many orders of magnitude lower than in metals .

It does n't neutralize electricity . It has a high electrical resistance , making it very difficult for electricity to pass through it . So if you 're wearing rubber gloves , you 're less likely to be shocked through your hands because of the gloves .

question: Why do AM and FM radio signals sound so different ? A show I listen to on FM in the afternoons replays the next morning on AM , why does the AM station sound so much different ? Please explain like I'm five.

AM and FM are separate methods of encoding and broadcasting radio signals . M works by modulating the amplitude of the signal according to the information being sent , while the frequency remains constant . This differs from FM technology in which sound is encoded by varying the frequency of the wave and the amplitude is kept constant . . This difference in signal type is what causes the sounds to change . AM has poorer sound quality compared with FM , but is cheaper and includes lower bandwidth making it ideal for having many stations in a small broadcast range . The first thing to understand is what the " M " means . The M means " modulation " . When a radio station broadcasts ( sends out , transmits , etc ) a signal , it uses what is called a " carrier wave " . You ca n't actually hear this signal , as it is a very high frequency ... way higher than your ears can detect . The actual music ( or talking ) is used at the radio station to change the constant nature of the carrier wave . This " change " is called modulation . It 's sort of " mixed in " . AM radio does this by altering the amplitude ( or volume or power ) of the carrier wave . FM does it by using it to change the frequency ( pitch ) of the carrier wave . Think of a rope tied to a wall . Grab one end of the rope and move your arm up and down . How high ( or low ) your arm gets is AM . Now move your arm up and down * the same distance * but change * how fast * you move your arm . That is FM . In radio , you can " put more information " in how fast you move your arm , compared to how high / low you can do it . ( This is called " bandwidth " ) In general , more sound information can be put in a typical FM signal , and so it tends to sound better . That 's also why you see stereo broadcasts ( left and right ear channels ) done almost always with FM .

question: What Happens In Your Body The Exact Moment You Fall Asleep ? Wow Guys , thanks for all your answers ! ! ! ! I learned so much today ! Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: See , you do n't actually fall asleep all at once . It 's more of a well - defined process that everyone makes their way through in their own time . I 'll attempt to explain it . ----------------------------------------------------------------------- You start off moving into what 's called Stage 1 , from being completely awake . When you first lay down to go to sleep , you pass from your awake state to what 's called Alpha state . You 've daydreamed before , right ? That 's basically Alpha state . You 're still mostly conscious , but you start to see some little bouts of color behind your eyes ( hypnogogic hallucinations ) and you start to feel more relaxed . After Alpha , you enter Theta state . Theta state is when you could technically be considered asleep . This is when you move completely into sleep paralysis ( have you felt like you were falling then woken up with a start ? that 's sleep paralysis setting in and you not being completely unaware when it happened ) . You 're still sleeping relatively lightly , but if you can get through this stage you move into deeper sleep . ----------------------------------------------------------------------- The next major stage of sleep is called Stage 2 . Your brain starts to produce short periods of rapid brain waves that are called Sleep Spindles . This is the precursor to what comes next in sleep , deep sleep . Your body temperature begins to drop and your heart rate slows down , settling you in for the night . ------------------------------------------------------------------------ You then enter Stage 3 . When you enter stage 3 , really slow brain waves called Delta waves start happening . This is the true transition between light and deep sleep . ------------------------------------------------------------------------ You then enter Stage 4 . Stage four is commonly referred to as Delta Sleep because of the brain waves associated with it . It 's a deep sleep that lasts for about thirty minutes . You are the technically the most asleep in this stage . ------------------------------------------------------------------------ Here 's where it gets interesting . There is another stage of sleep unlike all the others . It 's called Stage 5 , or REM sleep . REM stands for Rapid Eye Movement , your eyes literally start moving rapidly behind your eyelids . Your breathing rate increases , and your brain waves shoot up to almost as active as if you were awake . Your voluntary muscles become completely paralyzed , and you start dreaming . REM is also where most of the body 's repairs happen . REM sleep is what makes you feel rested when you wake up , and where the body actually rests and restores itself ( which is why you usually do n't feel rested after a night of drinking or smoking weed , they both inhibit REM sleep ) . ----------------------------------------------------------------------- These stages come in cycles . It takes roughly 90 minutes for you to go from awake into REM . The first cycle typically has a short REM period , but subsequent cycles increase the duration of REM . When we actually fall asleep , we go from stage 1 into 2 , then 3 , then 4 , but here 's where something curious happens . We then go from 4 to 3 , then 3 to 2 , then into REM . After REM , we usually return to stage 2 , then go back to 3 , 4 , then 3 , 2 , REM . We have as many cycles as we stay asleep for , when we wake up , feeling refreshed and ready or the day . ------------------------------------------------------------------------ I do n't know if that answered your question , but I hope it shed some light on the subject . Edit : formatting . Edit 2 : I 'll be here if anyone has any other questions they 'd like answered about this topic . Edit 3 : Holy crap ! Thanks for popping my gold cherry anon ! Much love ! < 3 Edit 4 : Wow this blew up ... Thanks for all the questions ! I 'm getting to them all , do n't worry !
Your brain begins to ( more or less)ignore all sensory input , and sleep paralysis sets in , so that you do n't " act out " your dreams and hurt yourself . Also , your brain waves change a lot .

1. Your muscles start to relax: As you start to fall asleep, your muscles begin to relax, especially in your face, neck, and limbs. You might notice that your arms and legs feel heavy and you might feel a tingling sensation in your hands and feet. 
2. Your breathing and heart rate slow down: As you fall deeper into sleep, your breathing and heart rate slow down. You might notice that your breaths become slower and deeper, and your heart rate becomes more regular. 
3. Your brain waves change: There are different types of brain waves, and the type of brain wave you have depends on what you're doing. When you're awake, your brain waves are fast and active. But as you fall asleep, your brain waves slow down and become more regular. 
4. Your body temperature drops: As you fall asleep, your body temperature drops slightly. This is why you might feel cold when you first go to bed, but then warm up as you fall asleep. 
5. Your body enters different stages of sleep: There are two main types of sleep: REM (rapid eye movement) sleep and non-REM sleep. Non-REM sleep is divided into three stages: light sleep, deep sleep, and very deep sleep. As you fall asleep, you move through these stages of sleep in a cycle that lasts about 90 minutes.

question: Why is the letter " W " pronounced " double - u " when " double - v " would seem to be more accurate ? Also , " W " is the only letter in the alphabet with more than one syllable . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: This goes back to the time when U and V were actually the same letter ; so , in fact , were I and J. This is what the classical Latin alphabet looked like : A B C D E F G H I K L M N O P Q R S T V X Y Z But in handwriting , it looked a bit more like this : * a b c d e f g h j k l m n o p q r s t u x y z * Notice that in the capital letters , there is no J or U ; and in the cursive letters , no * i * or * v * . Instead , you had the following capital / cursive pairs : I*j * and V*u * . So the name " Julius " would , in Latin , be carved in stone as " IVLIVS " , but written by hand as " * juljus * " . These letters could be used as vowels or consonants ; so the letter " I " as a vowel had a sound like the " i " in " sit " , and as a consonant a sound like the " y " in " yes " ; the letter " V " had as a vowel a sound like the " u " in " put " , and as a consonant ... well , it was either like our " w " , or like our " v " . The smart money is on " w " , but there were no tape recorders in those days so we ca n't be sure . But a word like " * uacuum * " might have been pronounced " wack - woom " , and explains why our word " vacuum " has two Us in it . The phrase " * uenj ujdj ujcj * " , which we usually spell " veni vidi vici " ( " I came , I saw , I conquered " ) might have been pronounced " wenny weedy weeky " or " wenny weedy wee - chee " ( again , we ca n't be sure ) . When the Roman alphabet was used to write other languages , those other languages often had sounds that did n't exist in Latin . Sometimes they added extra letters ( for example , the letters Ã and Ã , which are still used in modern Icelandic ) , sometimes they put two or more letters together to make a new sound ( for example , our TH ) . For some languages , a new letter was created by doubling the letter V -- so VV ; or , in cursive , * uu * . Hence the name , " double - U " . But additionally , the letters I and V were " split " , to make two versions of each -- originally , one for the vowel and one for the consonant . So the letter I*j * was split to make Ii for the vowel and Jj for the consonant ( which in modern English is now pronounced differently -- in modern German it 's still pronounced like our Y ) ; V*u * was similarly split to make Uu ( vowel ) and Vv ( consonant ) . The W took on the form of the V , but we kept the name " double - U " . This is actually appropriate , because the English " w " sound is , in effect , a very short " u " sound . Languages like French did n't originally have this letter , because it was n't needed -- except for writing foreign words , like " le weekend " . But since the W now looks like two Vs , the French called it " double - V " . Incidentally , although you might not think it , the sounds of " W " and " V " are , phonetically , very closely related . Native English speakers can hear the difference so clearly they do n't realise how similar they are ; many Germans , however , find it very difficult , and often confuse the sounds , saying " wiolin " instead of " violin " , for example . Both sounds are also very closely related to " U " .

question: If x^2 derived is 2x , why is n't sin^2 x derived = 2 sin x. Same goes for the integral / antiderivatives where integral of x is x^2/2 . But not for sin / cos . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: The chain rule . When you write sin^2 x ( a convenient notation ) as ( sin x)^2 the derivative is 2(sin x ) times the derivative of what is inside , which is cos x. So the derivative is 2(sin x)(cos x ) . We can actually use the chain rule in the derivative of x^2 but it 's sort of hidden . Write x^2 as ( x)^2 which has derivative 2x times the derivative of what is inside , which is 1 , but anything times 1 is itself so the derivative is just 2x . In general , the derivative of any differentiable function of the form f(g(x ) ) is f'(g(x))g'(x ) where f ' and g ' are the respective derivatives of f and g , and this is the chain rule . In your example , f(x)=x^2 and g(x)=sin x. Antiderivatives are more complicated because while it is easy to apply the chain rule in one direction ( derivatives ) , it is not so easy to go backwards ( antiderivatives ) . Sometimes u substitution works but not always .

You mean " differentiated , " not " derived . " For any function f(x ) , let 's differentiate ( f(x))^2 . By chain rule you get d / dx ( ( f(x))^2 ) = 2 f(x ) f'(x ) When f(x ) = x , you get f'(x ) = 1 so the derivative is just 2x . When f(x ) = sin(x ) , you get derivative of ( f(x))^2 = sin^2(x ) is 2 sin(x ) cos(x ) . So the answer is that when you differentiate the square of something there 's an extra term in the product due to chain rule , it 's just that when you 're trying to differentiate x^2 the extra term is 1 and ends up not mattering . FWIW I think sin^2(x ) is a bad and confusing notation , I much prefer ( sin(x))^2 , but changing standards that have been in use for decades or centuries is really hard .

It also works if you break it down into multiplication and eliminate the exponentials . So just use the rule for differentiating two functions that are multiplied together . d / dx ( f(x)*g(x ) ) = f'(x)*g(x)+f(x)*g'(x ) Or as I memorized it , " The derivative of two functions multiplied by each other is the derivative of the first times the second , plus the derivative of the second times the first " x^2 = x*x d / dx ( x^2 ) = d / dx ( xx ) d / dx ( xx ) = d / dx ( x)x+xd / dx(x ) d / dx ( x)x+x*d / dx(x ) = 1x+x1=2x now for sin(x ) ( sin(x))^2 = sin(x)*sin(x ) d / dx ( sin(x))^2 = d / dx ( sin(x)sin(x ) ) d / dx ( sin(x)sin(x))=d / dx(sin(x))sin(x)+sin(x)d / dx(sin(x ) ) d / dx(sin(x))sin(x)+sin(x)d / dx(sin(x))=cos(x)sin(x)+sin(x)cos(x ) cos(x)sin(x)+sin(x)cos(x)=2cos(x)sin(x ) Also , you could look at it from the physical representation perspective . Graph sin(x)^2 . Look at that , and try to figure out approximately what the derivative of that should look like ( ie a graph of the slope of that curve ) . Now graph 2sin(x ) . That 's obviously wrong ! It 's 2 when it should be zero ! Then try graphing 2sin(x)cos(x ) . Which one looks right ? The one that is right !
generated_answer:
Derivatives and integrals are operations that allow us to find the rate of change of a function or the area under a curve, respectively. The derivative of a function tells us how the function is changing at any given point, and the integral of a function gives us the total amount that the function has changed over a certain interval. 
The derivative of x^2 is 2x because x^2 is increasing at a rate of 2x at every point. In other words, if x is increasing by a small amount, then x^2 is increasing by twice that amount. This relationship is captured by the derivative of x^2, which is 2x. 
The derivative of sin^2 x, on the other hand, is not equal to 2 sin x. The derivative of sin^2 x is actually 2 sin x cos x. This is because sin^2 x is not increasing at a constant rate like x^2. Instead, the rate at which sin^2 x is increasing depends on the value of sin x and cos x at that point. When sin x is large and cos x is small, sin^2 x is increasing quickly. When sin x is small and cos x is large, sin^2 x is increasing more slowly. The derivative of sin^2 x takes this changing rate of change into account. 
Similarly, the integral of x is x^2/2 because the total amount that x has changed over a certain interval can be represented by the area of a rectangle with base x and height x/2. The integral of sin x or cos x, on the other hand, cannot be represented by a simple polynomial like x^2/2. Instead, these functions require more complex mathematical expressions to describe their total change over an interval.

question: How can our ribs " expand " ? Are the ribs completely static or can they expand somehow ? I 'd appreciate a thorough explanation on how the ribs interact with our organs and bodies . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: This rib cage is able to " expand " because each rib is attached at a movable joint to both the vertebrae and to the sternum via cartilage . The ribs do n't actually expand , they move up and down ( the angle up / down that they move is determined by the angle of the rib at the attachment to the vertebra ) . Upper ribs move more vertically ( think of the sternum as a well pump handle [ URL_0 ] , but with ribs coming off of it . That is the plane of movement of these ribs . So these ribs will be moving mostly up / down).The lower ribs have a more out and up sweeping type motion ( that is why when you inhale deeply the sides of your chest expand , because of this sweeping motion . ) There are a lot of muscles that interact with the ribs to facilitate this movement , most notably the diaphragm , but other muscles ( intercostals , serratus posterior , levator costorum , scaleneus ) act on the ribs to pull them up and down . Hope this helps

The areas between each rib are known as intercostal spaces and within these spaces are both interior and external intercostal muscles . Others have explained how they are connected to the vertebrae in the back and through hyaline cartilage at the sternum . Our ribs have a natural downward slope to them . The reason for this is so that when our external intercostal muscles contract with inspiration ( breathing in ) , the muscles physically raise the ribs to increase the size of the thoracic cavity by essentially just repositioning the ribs . This is possible because the connective tissue on the sternal end of the rib is hyaline cartilage which possesses elastic tendencies . The rib is not physically expanding , it is just being repositioned with help from the intercostal muscles , connective cartilage , and diaphragm . This is a fairly good gif to explain the repositioning of the rib cage to " expand " it that occurs with inspiration . ( URL_0 )

Your ribs are attached to your sternum ( " breastbone " , in the middle of your chest ) and to your backbone . The attachment to the backbone is a " gliding " joint -- it can move a small amount . The attachment at the front is not actually a joint at all . Instead , the ribs are connected to the sternum by strips of cartilage , rather than bone . The cartilage is somewhat flexible . Together , these things allow your ribcage to expand and contract a little bit as you breathe .
generated_answer:
The ribs are bones that are attached to the spine and help protect the organs in the chest, such as the heart and lungs. While the ribs are generally not able to move or expand on their own, they do move slightly when we breathe. 
When we inhale, or take a deep breath in, the muscles between the ribs, called the intercostal muscles, contract and pull the ribs upwards and outwards. This expands the chest cavity and creates more space for the lungs to fill with air. When we exhale, or breathe out, the intercostal muscles relax and the ribs return to their normal position. 
So, while the ribs themselves do not expand, the chest cavity can expand and contract when we breathe, which can make it seem like the ribs are expanding. This is an important part of the process of breathing and helps us get the oxygen we need to survive.

question: What is Unitarian Universalism ? I 've recently been trying to find myself in the world , and I came across Unitarian Universalism . I 've found a lot of mixed information . So , what is it ? Please explain like I'm five.

In a Christian context , it 's the doctrine that all souls , no matter how sinful , will be reconciled to God by his love and mercy . Unitarian Universalism is the meeting of these two doctrines . They hold that religion is a universal part of being human , they talk a lot about the things that religions have in common , and they are accepting of people from any and every religious background , because in the end , we 're all going to be with God , no matter what book we read from now .

And as they believed there was no reason to convert the infidels to save their souls , many also found inspiration in the commonalities between some of their traditions and those of other religions . From there it snowballed into a modern religion with no official doctrines , that is about a community dedicated to â a free and responsible search for truth and meaning â . As for myself I was raised Christian , became atheist / agnostic / it 's complicated , then adopted the teachings of Epicurus as a systematic philosophy of life , then since he emphasized having a community I found UU to be the one compatible with my beliefs / views / whatever . In our day - to - day activities we coordinate most frequently with our local Reform Jewish synagogue and United Church of Christ church .

question: Why race car tires have more traction without treads but consumer tires have more traction with treads . Uh , see title . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: Not including the compound of the rubber ( race ties being softer , and usually of a different chemical makeup ) , the difference comes down to water and heat cycles . Race tires without treads make the most contact , but they are used only in the dry . Consumer tires have to handle multiple conditions , including water . The treads channel water away from the tires surface , allowing the tire to make contact with the road instead of floating on top of the water . Consumer tires have far less traction when " bald " usually due to heat cycling , and the fact the the compound at that level is often different than the compound at the surface when a tire is newer . Heat cycling is essentially the hardening of the rubber each time the tire warms up and cools down . The harder the tire , the less grip . Many racers that are restricted to " street " tires will often shave tread off of brand new tires to reduce the amount of tread " squirm " and often get to a different compound ( if the tire is molded in such a way ) .

Treads are really only better for driving in the rain . If it 's not raining , you tires have more traction on asphalt / concrete if they 're smooth . But smooth tires are terrible in the rain , so having treads is necessary for our cars .

The treads on consumer tires are a trade off . In dry conditions they provide less traction than a racing slick would . In wet conditions , the treads displace water allowing the tire to grip the road , whereas racing tires would just slide .
generated_answer:
Race car tires are designed to provide maximum grip and traction on a racetrack. They are made of a special rubber compound that is very sticky and helps the tires adhere to the track surface. In addition, race car tires are generally very smooth and have no treads. This is because treads can actually reduce grip on a smooth surface like a racetrack. 
On the other hand, consumer tires are designed to be used on the road and are therefore built to handle a variety of surfaces and conditions. Treads on consumer tires help to provide grip on wet or slippery roads by channeling water away from the tire and increasing the tire's contact with the road. Treads also help to provide traction on loose or uneven surfaces, such as gravel or dirt roads. 
In summary, race car tires have more traction without treads because they are designed specifically for use on smooth, dry racetracks. Consumer tires have more traction with treads because they need to be able to handle a variety of road conditions, including wet and slippery surfaces.

question: Why are the ceilings in so many grocery stores so high ? Does n't this increase both initial building costs and subsequent heating costs ? Edit : Thank you to everyone who helped to answer my question . I had no idea so many factors were involved . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: It makes the store feel open and less crowded , and it lets you set up displays that take advantage of the height , such as signs visible anywhere in the store . It also makes moving things with machinery like forklifts easier . Psychological experiments have shown that people do n't like being in areas with low ceilings . Some airports have made use of low ceilings in places where they do n't want people to linger , like the front of the check in line . edit : check in , not check out .

The greatest benefit to height is in the event of a fire . Higher ceilings allow more time for smoke and heat to accumulate before affecting things closer to the floor ( e.g. , people , fire load / combustibles ) . The height also can allow for fire suppression systems that cover a greater area with fewer components , such as sprinkler heads . In addition , it is generally easier to control the climate in a larger space with larger air volumes ( exchanges per hour ) that are not as noticeable in one spot . ( Except for those annoying freeze - or - fry areas where air flows are concentrated . ) The air handlers in these systems can also be configured for use following a fire to assist in evacuating smoke from a building , either by exhaust or pressurizing the building ( negative and positive pressure ventilation , respectively ) . Construction costs would tend to be slightly higher because of the longer ( higher ) columns required , which in turn need to be stronger because of ( typically ) larger roof systems such as bar joists or trusses . Such costs can be somewhat offset by reducing the number of columns required . When designers are tasked to create ' open space ' , regardless of low or high ceilings , larger columns with stronger roof systems allow column spacing to be increased , thus ' opening ' the space . However , this is not always the case , such as in multi - story structures where significant weight / loads on higher floors require different column sizes or spacing ( e.g. , airports , parking ramps , hotels ) . Operating costs do tend to be higher , but it is a trade off on the desired space / affect and what is considered reasonable operating expense . Such factors are taken into consideration during the design phase of projects , so the owner / operator knows early - on what to expect . These factors also contribute to changes in a design if costs are deemed to be unreasonable or exceeding targets / goals . Source : Engineer by day , Firefighter by night . question: What does it mean to refinance a house ? I know someone who is refinancing their house . He was telling me about it , but I really could n't follow . So what happens ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: Most people take out a loan to buy a house and they use the house as collateral for the loan . This means that if you do n't pay the loan , the bank can take the house and sell it to get its money back . These loans are called mortgages . They have certain terms , such as the interest rates and over how many years the loan has to be paid off . When you refinance you find a lender who loans you the money to pay off the original mortgage . You once again use your house as collateral for the new loan and now have a mortgage with a different lender . People refinance to get better terms on their mortgage . If your original mortgage has an interest rate of 6 % but you can get a new one with a 4 % interest rate you can save money by refinancing . Reasons you may be able to get a lower interest rate include better credit on your part ( maybe your credit score rose since you took out the original loan ) or a better lending environment ( federal interest rates are low so banks are generally giving lower interest loans ) .
Basically you get a new loan under new terms to pay off the old loan . It 's typically done to get a lower interest rate or perhaps to change the lenght of the loan .

Shelter is expensive . There are basically three options to have shelter : * ( a ) Free shelter ( from someone else who is paying for it ) * ( b ) Rented shelter ( temporarily having possession of property that is owned by someone else ) * ( c ) Owned shelter ( the property is yours ) Let 's say Bob wants shelter . Charlie owns a home . If Bob wants to live in Charlie 's home , he may offer to pay rent every week / month in order to have permission to live inside of Charlie 's property . The relationship between Bob and Charlie is called a " landlord - tenant relationship , " and has its own laws and rules that each must follow . In the end , though , Bob is responsible for compensating Charlie for a % of the value Charlie has lost in his home ( because now he must share a part of it with Bob ) . This payment is a fraction of the value of Charlie 's home because Bob only enjoys a fraction of its benefit . One day , Bob decide 's he loves the home but dislikes living with Charlie . It so - happens that Charlie is looking to move to a different state . Charlie offers to sell his home to Bob for the " fair market value " ( what the average buyer would pay ) of his home : $ 200,000 . Like most people , Bob does n't have $ 200,000 , so he goes to find someone who does ( a " lender " ) . The Lender , usually a bank , has a lot of money and it makes money based on loaning it out to people . There is a cost to a loan . If a Lender gives you a $ 100 loan , due in a week , at 10 % interest , then in 1 week you will need to pay the Lender back $ 110 . In exchange for you having access to $ 100 immediately , the " cost " of the service was $ 10 . Here , the Lender will look at the potential deal between Bob and Charlie . They will see that Charlie has a house worth $ 200,000 , and Bob is willing to promise to buy it and pay for it over time . Using various calculations , risk assessments , and other economic factors , the Lender decides that Bob is worthy of a loan . It is common for Bob to have to pay at least a portion of the $ 200,000 ( 1 to 3 % ) , but the rest of that $ 200,000 will be paid from the Lender to Charlie on behalf of Bob . Once everything " closes " ( finalizes / goes through / is paid ) , Bob now owns Charlie 's house , * * subject * * to a mortgage owned by the Lender . In this case , Bob is paying $ X per month for 30 years with an interest rate of Y% . After 30 years , Bob will have paid well over $ 200,000 for the home ... how much over depends on the interest rate and his initial cash payment . Bob loves his house . He is making his mortgage payments , and life is good . In fact , 3 years later , there is a boom in the housing market and Bob 's house is now worth $ 400,000 . This means that if Bob were to sell his house today , he would be paid $ 400,000 and , from that , he would pay off the remainder of his loan to the Lender and make a profit of , say , $ 200,000 ( for the sake of keeping things simple ) . But what if Bob does n't want to sell the home ? That unrealized profit of $ 200,000 is called " equity . " Bob may want to " cash - out " on that $ 200,000 in equity in order to invest it in other stuff , which would require the Lender to agree to " refinance " ( modify ) the original agreement . Now , Bob owes $ 400,000 on his $ 400,000 home , but has received $ 200,000 cash . The most common reason to refinance , though , is a change in interest rates . Remember that when the Lender originally reviewed Bob for a loan , it made its offer based on many factors . Over time , those factors can change considerably . If , for example , the Lender had given Bob an interest rate of 10 % , but now interest rates are at 5 % , then it would save Bob a lot of money to negotiate with the Lender in order to reduce the interest rate to 5 % . Does the Lender need to ? No . Bob and Lender have an agreement already . However , if the Lender can figure out a way to increase its profit on the agreement ( for example , if the house is now worth more money ) , then it will be worth it to agree to receive less money in mortgage in exchange for a more valuable security . In other words ... remember how Lenders make money by lending money ? They do n't want Charlie 's house . So if Bob decided to immediately stop making payments on his mortgage after buying it , then the Lender would have been stuck with a $ 200,000 house that it paid about $ 200,000 for . But after 3 years when the house is worth $ 400,000 , if Bob stops making payments then the Lender has the ability to quickly recoup the money it is owed from the sale of the home , even if it has to sell it slightly below market value . So Refinancing provides a way for Bob to use the increased value of his property to reduce the cost of his loan to Lender because the increased value of the property also reduces the risk to Lender that it will be able to get the money it is owed . For the Lender , best case scenario = Bob pays the exact amount of money agreed upon within the time frame agreed upon . Worst case scenario = Bob fails to pay , but Lender will be able to sell the home to someone else that will pay that bill . * * tl;dr :* * Refinancing takes into account all the various factors that have changed since the time an agreement was originally made and adjusts the agreement in a way that is mutually beneficial to the borrower and the Lender .
generated_answer:
When you refinance a house, you are essentially taking out a new loan to pay off your existing mortgage. This can be done for a variety of reasons, such as to get a lower interest rate, to change the length of the loan, or to access the equity you have built up in your home. 
Here's an example of how refinancing might work: 
Let's say that you have a mortgage on your home with an interest rate of 5%. You've been paying on this mortgage for a few years and have built up some equity in your home. Now, you find out that you can refinance your mortgage and get a new loan with an interest rate of 4%. This would mean that you would be paying less in interest each month, which would lower your monthly mortgage payments. 
To do this, you would need to apply for a new mortgage and go through the process of getting approved for the loan. Once you have been approved, the lender will pay off your old mortgage and give you a new loan with the lower interest rate. You will then make payments on this new loan instead of the old one. 
Overall, refinancing a house can be a good way to save money on your mortgage payments or to access the equity you have built up in your home. However, it's important to consider all of the costs associated with refinancing, such as closing costs, to make sure that it makes financial sense for you.

Milk teeth are different from permanent teeth in a few ways. For one thing, they are smaller and more delicate than permanent teeth. They also have different shapes and are arranged differently in the mouth. Milk teeth also have thinner enamel, the hard outer layer that protects teeth, which makes them more prone to cavities. 
One of the reasons that children lose their milk teeth is because they are simply not strong enough to last a lifetime. human_answer: The victory for dominance comes when the an animal has established dominance over the other . Whenever the other animal feels powerless to continue , the dominating animal will psychologically feel being " in charge " . The other animal might feel " under control " , and thus he / she is n't dominative . How an animal " knows " who won the fight is how their minds make them feel . Dying is not necessary for this to happen , mere circumstances can be enough to induce these feelings . In battles of power , the classic psychological reactions are " fight " , " flight " and " freeze " . Flight and freeze automatically assert submission over the situation , as the animal feels that he / she is unable to fight and thus is n't dominative . Fight on the other hand implies dominance , and if both of the animals fight , whoever switches either to " flight " or " freeze " first loses dominance . Much of this happens also in the human world . For example , if you have a debate with someone , and you win by your arguments , then you may feel dominative . And conversely , if you lose , you may feel submissive .

If the other animal runs away , it lost . It 's that simple

For example, if one animal is clearly submitting to the other by lowering their head, averting their gaze, or making submissive noises, it may be clear to the other animal that they have won the fight. Similarly, if one animal is able to drive the other animal away or make them retreat, it may be clear that they have won the fight. 
It's also important to note that animals don't always have to fight to determine dominance. In some cases, they may use other forms of communication, such as vocalizations or gestures, to establish their dominance without physically engaging in a fight. 
In general, animals have developed a variety of ways to communicate with each other and establish social hierarchies, and they are often able to understand these signals and determine who has won a fight or other competition without resorting to lethal violence.

question: Why are smoothbore cannons more prevalent in modern tanks when we previously hailed rifled guns as a large advancement e.g. M1 , AMX Leclrec , etc Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: Smooth bores allow the firing of complex projectiles that might pop out fins for example , or have aerodynamics which should n't be disturbed . Rifling actually cuts into the projectile and would cause harm to such a tank round . Instead modern rounds use sabots which allow a wide variety of projectile shapes .

The M1 actually originally used a rifled barrel before the A1 upgrade replaced it with a smoothbore system . The British and Indian Main Battle Tanks still retain rifled barrels . Smoothbore barrels do n't wear as fast as rifled barrels , so maintenance is a consideration but it depends largely on the ammunition you want to use . Your choice of munitions will be informed by who you expect to be fighting and what sort of fighting it will be - big open terrain tank battles ( as envisaged taking place in W.Germany during the Cold War ) , or in - town anti - insurgency , anti - personnel fighting where the enemy have no tanks or heavy armour . If you want to use fin - stabilised rounds for accurate long range shooting and some of the newer anti - personnel rounds ( which are basically glorified shotgun cartridges that fire multiple projectiles simultaneously ) then a smoothbore barrel is good . If you want to use traditional spin - stabilised high explosive shells then a rifled barrel is required . The invasion of Iraq and Afghanistan was one of the reasons for the Americans to move to a smooth - bore barrel - the fighting there involved very little anti - tank activity and was mostly anti - personnel and anti - building , which called for munitions better served through a smooth - bore barrel .

So here 's the thing about most technology breakthroughs ; they 're not really inventing new ideas , they 're just using old ideas in a new way . Smooth bores were terrible when we had " dumb " projectiles , so we rifled the bores to correct for bad bullets . Well now , we invented complex bullets that do many things on their own , so a rifle bore gets in the way . Now we 're back to smooth bores . As the see - saw of innovation continues , technologies come in and out of usefulness , but never truly go away .
generated_answer:
Rifled guns are still used in modern tanks, but smoothbore cannons have become more prevalent for a few reasons. 
One reason is that smoothbore cannons can fire a wider variety of ammunition, including fin-stabilized projectiles and shaped charges, which can be effective against certain types of armor. Rifled guns, on the other hand, are typically limited to firing kinetic energy projectiles. 
Another reason is that smoothbore cannons can fire projectiles at higher velocities, which can be useful for defeating modern armor. This is because the smooth bore allows the projectile to maintain a higher velocity as it travels down the barrel, whereas the rifling in a rifled gun can cause the projectile to slow down slightly. 
Finally, smoothbore cannons are generally simpler and cheaper to manufacture, which can be an important consideration when designing military equipment. 
Overall, the choice between using a rifled gun or a smoothbore cannon in a tank often comes down to the specific role that the tank is intended to play and the types of threats it is likely to encounter. Both types of guns have their own advantages and disadvantages, and both can be effective in the right circumstances.

question: Why have n't we dug to the Earth 's Core yet ? Are n't we all curious as to what s REALLY down there ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: Easy answer : its too hot . The deepest man made hole is Kola Superdeep Borehole . That was a Russian experiment to see how deep you could drill into earths crust , reaching down 12,262 meters . At that depth the temperature reached 180 Â° C . The scientists estimated that a 15,000 meters depth the temperature would reach 300 Â° C , and at that temperature the drill would cease to work and the project was stopped .

The distance to the core is around 3000 km deep . The crust is 30 - 65 km deep . The current record depth we have dug is 12 km . We have n't even reached half way through the crust let alone even get a tiny tiny fraction toward the core . The earth is a big place and digging down far is really hard .

Others have answered why we have n't gone further down and I would summarize by saying that , ignoring everything else , it 's so hot it would melt anything we could use to dig . But there are ways to understand the interior of the Earth aside from digging . One is similar to sonar , which is how bats " see " by bouncing sounds off of it . Earthquakes provide the " sound " and we monitor how those waves bounces off the layers to understand the structure of the Earth . Then we use our understanding of the rules of physics and chemistry to see what the temperature and pressure is at those regions and it gives us an idea of what the structures are made of . We can compare this kind of thing to lava ( which is the material from the layer between the crust and the core ) to see if we 're on to something . To look at the core we use the same kind of approach but we do n't have core material . So we look at what might be there -- heavy stuff like iron and nickel that was around when the planet formed , the magnetic field that we think comes from the movement of the material in the core , and how the planet spins on its axis . We are stuck with these indirect measures , which in some ways is unfortunate , but it 's just as well because if we could get down there we 'd burn up before we could write any notes .

The Earth's core is a very difficult place to reach, and it's not something that humans have been able to do yet. The core is located about 3,000 kilometers (1,800 miles) below the surface of the Earth, and it's made up of mostly iron and nickel. It's extremely hot down there, with temperatures reaching up to 5,500 degrees Celsius (9,932 degrees Fahrenheit). 
To reach the core, we would have to dig through a lot of rock and other materials, which would be very hard and time-consuming. Plus, the extreme heat and pressure at the core would make it very dangerous for humans to be there. 
So while it might be interesting to know what's at the Earth's core, it's not something that we can easily do right now. Scientists are still learning about the Earth's core through other methods, like studying how the Earth's magnetic field works and how earthquakes and other natural disasters happen.

question: can a submarine stop and hover at the same depth like a helicopter , or does it need to continue to be on the move in order not to sink like a plane , how \ why ? edit : thank you guys;great answers :-) Please explain like I'm five.
human_answer: In principle a submarine can stop and maintain depth , but they tend not to be very good at it . This is because , when stopped , they have to rely on trim tanks ( which can pump water in and out ) to adjust the buoyancy to keep the submarine at completely neutral buoyancy , as any small difference will cause the submarine to slowly drift up or down . This tends not to be a very accurate process , plus you are then susceptible to any upwards or downwards currents . So typically submarines will maintain a very slow speed ( 1 - 3 knots , if memory serves ) when they want to hold position , because that allows them to use their dive planes ( the little wings that are on the sides of the submarine ) . The dives planes can react quickly to changes in depth / buoyancy and can also help keep the submarine level . Source : I played some very detailed submarine simulation games recently , and this was mentioned in the ( very long ) manuals .

They can stop and be still . It 's hard because of underwater currents but when the motors stop , they kinda float around like a bath toy . They only do this though when they need to run silent . Most of the time they can just keep heading their course .
A submarine is more like a blimp than a plane . It pumps water in or out of ballast tanks to maintain neutral buoyancy . It is floating in the water , not flying through it .
generated_answer:
Submarines can stop and hover at a certain depth in the water, just like a helicopter can hover in the air. However, unlike a helicopter, a submarine doesn't use any special equipment to stay in one place. Instead, it uses something called "neutral buoyancy" to hover in the water. 
Buoyancy is the force that makes objects float or sink. When an object is more buoyant, it will float, and when it is less buoyant, it will sink. A submarine can control its buoyancy by taking in or letting out water from special tanks called "ballast tanks." 
When a submarine wants to go down, it takes in water into its ballast tanks, making it more dense and less buoyant. When it wants to go up, it lets the water out of its ballast tanks, making it less dense and more buoyant. By carefully controlling the amount of water in its ballast tanks, a submarine can hover at a certain depth in the water without sinking or rising. 
So, to sum it up, a submarine can stop and hover in the water by using its ballast tanks to control its buoyancy.
